title: NW2 Midi soft thru
post_content: The midi soft thru on (my?) NW2 is not working. The specs say it should:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/products/ ... ificationsI'm sending midi data on two channels from my N2EX (midi out) to NW2 (midi in). I have NW2 (midi out) going to Jupiter XM (midi in).The Jupiter XM is not recieving anything from the N2EX going thru NW2.I've set (to check) the Jupiter Xm midi setting on Remote Kbd [midi in] (that would result in playing on every incoming midi channel), but still no sound when playing N2EX.To make sure the cable or midi out from NW2 is not broken, the Jupiter plays fine if I play it from the NW2.Global channel on NW2 is on, and not set to off.I've tried a different setup, instead of the NW2 I used my MC707. With the MC707 the soft thru works fine.So is it a bug? Is it not ment to work on the NW2?

title: RE: NW2 Midi soft thru
post_content: Seems like they have either skipped or forgot it, or wrote it by an error in the specifications. I briefly went through the user manual, and it was not mentioned anywhere like on the other models. There use to be an setting for it in the Midi menu, at least on my NS and A1.Maybe try to shoot them an email on their support page. It might be added in a future update, or not.

title: RE: NW2 Midi soft thru
post_content: missoundscape wrote:I'm sending midi data ontwochannels from my N2EX (midi out) to NW2 (midi in).[...]Global channel on NW2 is on, and not set to off.I am not familiar with the Wave 2, but if it behaves similarly to the Stage 3, the Global can only receive ononechannel. It's either OFF altogether, or it is set to that specific channel you want to send to and receive from. It can't be just "ON". But you are saying you are sending ontwoseparate channels from your N2EX (which I assume to mean NS2EX). Which are those two channels, and is the Global channel of the Wave 2 set to either one of those?

title: RE: NW2 Midi soft thru
post_content: I just tested this and it appears you might have found a bug, or the specs are just incorrect.I just used a single global midi channel (7) to send note data to the NW2 from my NS3, which always works fine.  I then connected a drum module on the same channel to the Midi out of the NW2.  When I played a note on the NW2, I could trigger sounds on the drum module.  When played from the NS3, no midi data reached the drum module even though the midi data was indeed reaching the NW2 (midi led active). This was the same regardless of whether the NW2 was using the global channel or the layer channel. It is clear that there is no midi through on the NW2.-dj

title: NW2 Chorale (Reverb)
post_content: Nord Wave 2 got this thing called Chorale which can be turned on for Reverb.To me it sounds like a pitch shift thing out of control, the modulation is too deep for my taste and the speed of the modulation is too fast for my taste.It kinda sound flanger'ish used on a clean Saw waveform.The point behind modulated reverbs is to create a little movement in a non vibrato sound.Chorale is useless to me as it is.Anyone else getting good use of Chorale ?

title: RE: NW2 Chorale (Reverb)
post_content: I find it useful on sustained String or Choir sounds.

title: RE: NW2 Chorale (Reverb)
post_content: I think it can be good on pads, maybe the guitar sounds...but I much prefer external pedals for this kind of thing (same with delay.) You get a lot more control because those units are specifically designed for that purpose; the Nord effects are just to provide the option for an all-in-one system if you want it. I do agree the modulation should have been at a slower rate and shallower depth though, it would be useful in a wider amount of applications. When I use reverb pedals I always have at least a tiny amount of modulation on simply to add movement as you say.

title: . nsmp vs nsmp3 question
post_content: Hi, I don't have much experience with Nord Wave2 , and I need help.These days I bought a package of programs for NW2 in which there was a bonus of samples. These samples are in .nsmp formatAs far as I know, (I read in the forum) the current format that reads (loads) NW2 is .nsmp3Can I load .nsmp in NW2, or if I can't, is there any software available, convert them. While browsing the forum, I came across an article about .nsmp3 converter, but the link to it leads nowhere, there is no information on Nord's official website.I also have an additional question - can sounds be converted from A1, I'm not good at programming, and I really like some of them. Can they be found somewhere. I will also be happy to recommend (if any) 80s / 90s synth programs.

title: RE: . nsmp vs nsmp3 question
post_content: Hi and welcome to the forum!You can use both sample formats for your NW2, the Nord Sound Manager software converts the old .nsmp format into the current .nsmp3 format when you load the sample to the NW2.Can't really answer your question about converting A1 sounds to NW2 since I don't own any of them, but I doubt it's possible to convert them automatically since these are different products. The only way might be to manually try to rebuild the A1 sounds on the NW2 as much as possible (if at all)

title: RE: . nsmp vs nsmp3 question
post_content: While browsing the forum, I came across an article about .nsmp3 converter, but the link to it leads nowhere, there is no information on Nord's official website.This converter was released by clavia during the transition from old sample format to the new one as the new sample editor was not available yet and the old one could not do the convertion. That was just temporary for that sort period and there is no use for it any more. What I really wish for is a converter that does the opposite, as there are lots of great nsmp3 samples that I would like to be able to use with my older gear. I don't believe that clavia will ever make one though, as it would prevent people from buying newer instruments in some degree.Regarding your other question about A1 to NW I'm pretty sure there is no way to do it as they are two completely different instruments with different structure. Sampling the sound of A1 and loading on the wave is a workaround but It won't be eexactly the same. If the original sound involves movement and other articulations you will have a hard time adjusting the loops properly.

title: RE: . nsmp vs nsmp3 question
post_content: Thanks for responding.Really very useful information for me, because I have not yet installed any of the available software, there was no way to know.

title: RE: . nsmp vs nsmp3 question
post_content: All you really need is sound manager. It wil help you organize the sounds of your instrument, rearrange them, delete samples and programs you don't need and load new ones of your taste. It gives you a clear image of what is inside your keyboard and you can always create a back-up or load a previous one. The sample editor is designed for creating your own samples, so it's not essential if this is not your intention, it's fun and intriguing to try it though.

title: RE: . nsmp vs nsmp3 question
post_content: I will also have to correct my self regarding the sample converter. It was not the old sample editor that could not do the conversion, but the sound manager. They later upgrated sound manager inorder to do automaticlly the conversion if a newer nord model was connected. Later on they released the new version of sample editor so that custom made samples could be saved in nsmp3 format, as well as some new features that make the procedure easier and faster.

Nord Wave 2 Sample and filter
post_content: Hi I have a question for the north wave 2, why don't the filters work in the sample mode?Thank you

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 Sample and filter
post_content: Samples start with filter ON or OFF, it depends on which sample you have loaded. If you want filter ON and the sample have defalt to filter OFF then you just activate the filter.Same goes for AMP VEL.SKIP ATK is used in situations where you like the sound of a sample but like to skip the initial attack of the sample.

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 Sample and filter
post_content: Thanks a lot for the answer!  I didn't understand it, I found them now in the oscillator section.I'm happy!Andrea

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 Sample and filter
post_content: Turns out AMP VEL settings are different from sample to sample.In general samples can default to various AMP VEL settings depending on which sample you are using.Its up to you to alter that, same goes for the filter.

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 Sample and filter
post_content: mkastrup wrote:It appears NW2 got 4 modes for playing back samples:Mode 0 BASIC, with AMP VEL ON and Filter OFFMode 1 SKIP ATK, with AMP VEL ON and Filter OFF.Mode 2 RAW SMP, AMP VEL OFF and Filter ONMode 3 SKIP ATK, AMP VEL OFF and Filter ONSKIP ATK is used in situations where you like the sound of a sample but like to skip the initial attack of the sample.wait...does this mean that on the Wave 2, when using a sample it's impossible to have velocity AND filter active at the same time?

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 Sample and filter
post_content: No, Not at all.  None of the buttons described above need to be turned on.  You can just turn on the filter and then adjust the Amp velocity to taste--dj

title: Nord Wave 2 filter drive vs Nord Stage 3
post_content: I have my Nord Stage 3 compact and the new Nord Wave 2 i got a couple of days ago, side by side.I see that the filter drive on the Nord Wave 2 isn't as aggressive as on the Nord Stage 3. In fact, when i set it (on the NW2) to '1' it's barley noticeable - whereas on the NS3 a filter drive set to '1' would make a difference. Not to mention level '2' and '3'.Do you guys hear the same difference?

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 filter drive vs Nord Stage 3
post_content: I don't have a stage, so I can't answer, but I have a comparative question for you  since YOU have a stage.The range from 0-10, when you're dealing with lower settings there are noticeable and comparable differences in the amount of filter drive between the two. How do the higher settings compare? If you're going from a 10 down to a 9(or 8, or 7) do you find that you notice an equally big difference between the stage and wave? Does the Wave get up to the same 10 that the stage does, does it go further, does it not get up to the same level, etc.?My initial thought (again, without having a stage) is that the wave would be designed to have greater control of synth-levels than the stage. Maybe the levels on the stage ramp up and  flatten out at a certain point between 0-10, where the wave just keeps going steady?That being said, I wish I could really go balls out with literally every parameter, but I've noticed the same thing you have. It's just not particularly aggressive, which is a great way to put it.

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 filter drive vs Nord Stage 3
post_content: beepbeepjacob wrote:I don't have a stage, so I can't answer, but I have a comparative question for you  since YOU have a stage.The range from 0-10, when you're dealing with lower settings there are noticeable and comparable differences in the amount of filter drive between the two. How do the higher settings compare? If you're going from a 10 down to a 9(or 8, or 7) do you find that you notice an equally big difference between the stage and wave? Does the Wave get up to the same 10 that the stage does, does it go further, does it not get up to the same level, etc.?I think you're confusing "Filter Drive" (which is in the filter section) - and the drive in the amp/eq section.The filter drive in the filter section has only 3 levels: '1', '2' and '3'.  '1' being the lowest level of drive, '2' in the middle and '3' the highest.

title: RE: Strange noise on moving any poti, controller Nord Wave 2
post_content: It only seems to affect controls that send MIDI data out. The main volume knob, for example, doesn't do it, nor does the waveform control. title: RE: Strange noise on moving any poti, controller Nord Wave 2

title: RE: Strange noise on moving any poti, controller Nord Wave 2

title: RE: Strange noise on moving any poti, controller Nord Wave 2

title: RE: Strange noise on moving any poti, controller Nord Wave 2
post_content: I had a setup together with a stage 3 and a Yamaha Bluetooth midi so that I could get commands from my iPad. The stage had a y-midi-plug one port for the wave and the other one for the Yamaha device.Removing the Yamaha device fixed the problem.

title: RE: Grand Piano Sound for Nord Wave 2
post_content: Yes, they are different product lines, the NW2 is a Synthesizer and the Stage 3 is a Stage piano with synth capabilites. The difference in feature sets makes sense to me--dj

title: RE: Grand Piano Sound for Nord Wave 2
post_content: A nsmp sample is by far inferior to a npno file due to the lack of velocity layers. However, you can always cheat a little with the help of the W2 layers. You can assign different piano samples to each layer, or the same if you wish, and then tweak the settings of each layer (filter, eq, etc) then you can morph the amplitude of each layer inorder to achieve those variations. It will not be perfect realistic piano sound but at least there will be some motion.PS. I am not sure if the W2 features velocity morphing like the original but if it does it would be great for this.

title: RE: Grand Piano Sound for Nord Wave 2
post_content: Yes, the W2 has velocity morph. I am working on getting some piano velocity layer sample sets to do exactly this.

post_content: Oh cool will you share them once you are doneThanks for all the input. I know of course that they differ from the piano library samples. But still they could be better than those that are there currently.

title: NW2 Pattern Pan and Ping Pong Delay
post_content: When using arp pattern with pan right and ping pong delay there is NO delay.1. Select an empty preset2. Press Hold3. Press Arp run then set it to master clk 1/84. Press Shift+Pattern in Arp section5. Press Shift+Program Key 56. Delete all gates but keep the first.7. Turn on delay, then set it to master clk 1/8d8. Make that first gate pan right9. Make it pan center.10. Make it pan left.11. You should have heard delay on the 3 pan positions.12. Now turn on Ping Pong for the delay.13. Set Pan to center.14. Set Pan to right.15. Why did the delay stop ?16. Try alter the delay clk divisions. Nothing happens.17. Turn of ping pong from delay.18. Its a miracle, delay is back and at all clk divisions.19. Now turn on ping pong again. whoa...delay is gone again.Everyone who thinks this is normal, hands up

title: RE: NW2 Pattern Pan and Ping Pong Delay
post_content: Nord have confirmed the bug and will look into it for a future update fix. Yay

title: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: Hello, I just purchased a nord wave 2 off reverb. Came packaged well, everything is pristine, feels almost brand new.But the mod wheel doesn't work.... AT ALL. I tried modulating many of the patches with "WHL" in the patch name, and also set up just a basic patch with filter cutoff modulation with the mod wheel, no response, it seems to do absolutely nothing.Is their any settings I am overlooking here ? (I looked through all the system settings and didn't see anything related to the mod wheel), is their any explanation to this type of behaviour ?Hard to believe its just fully broken and disconnected from the circuit board etc...Any advice appreciated, thank you- DanPS. is their a tech support forum I should post this message in ?Also, does the OLED display show anything numerically when the mod wheel is being moved ?

title: RE: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: Try this.Power on your NW2Find an empty preset slot (bank P should have some)Turn filter FREQ fully downHold WHEEL modknob in the MORPH section.While holding the WHEEL modknob down turn filter FREQ fully up.Now use the ModWheel to hear if the filter FREQ opens op.If nothing happens then i guess its a faulty unit.The little MIDI led light next to the OLED display should flicker when using the ModWheel.

title: RE: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: I tried a simple test like this before, and it didn't work,But I just tried what you said using an empty bank... Damn its not looking good, the wheel does nothing, and I don't get any midi light activity or any indicator anywhere that the knob is moving.I guess I'll contact nord nowThanks for the help though!- Dan

title: RE: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: If you bought it second hand by reverb I think you should contact them first. Did you get any kind of guarrantee that could cover the repair cost? If you contact clavia they will probably prompt you to your local dealer.Another solution is to find an experienced technician in your town and let him check it. Removing the top cover is an easy task (you can also do it yourself with a screwdriver) and the MW mechanism is very easy to access and check connections. I did the same with my original wave sometime ago when the MW didn't stay in place. I bet there is not much difference between all nord keyboards in the way the chasis is assmblied.

title: RE: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: Just for your information, the mod wheel on my Nord Wave 2 stopped working after six months. The synth never left my studio and received light use. It seems that the assembly failed. As I don't have mechanical chops I'm having it repaired once I'm fully vaccinated. I'm using the mod wheel from my Nord Stage3 Compact to control it and a foot pedal in the meantime. I mention all of this because possibly this is an issue with the Nord Wave 2. I've owned five or six Nords over the years and I never experienced Mod Wheel failure before. Anyway, best of luck getting it fixed. It's such an essential aspect of using the Nord Wave 2!

Doesn't seem like a midi indicator should be indicating midi messages when there are none.

title: RE: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: Ok it was because i had a MIDI loop. My NW2 is also a master keyboard for my setup and recieves MIDI back from the other connections and thats why i saw MIDI flicker when using ModWheel.

title: RE: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: Hey guys, after searching the forum and realizing its a very common problem, I just took the necessary screws out, opened up and sure enough the connector cable was loose and barely attached! I just pushed it in, closed it back up and it works fine now!It must have came loose during shipping. A clampy/clicky style connector would fix this problem for nord in the future, if you guys are listening ?Otherwise, totally fixed and was easy as heck to do.Thank you to everyone that replied.

title: RE: Wave 2 Mod wheel not working
post_content: A loose connection is what I suspected when I read your post. Nice that you managed to fix it without having to send it away and pay extra money!

title: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: I ran in to trouble trying this.I have a multi sample and I'm happy with the splitpoints and key-to-pitch relationship.Now I want to combine it with a sligh high pitch shimmer from osc1.I find no way to change to octave of osc1 and if I pitch down osc2/sample the whole key-to-pitch relationship gets ruined (in practice formants will be shifted one octave). I can not use the octave shift since it changes both oscillators. I would need a separate octave shift for either oscillator1 or oscillator2.If I've made the multisample myself I can indeed shift the whole rootnote/zone structure in the Sample Editor but that's rather unpractical and produces a reduntant copy of the sample wasting precious memory space. If I've not made the sample myself there's no way to even do it this way.Is this impossible without using the second slots (also a waste of voices and a limitiation for other possibilities) or did I miss some important aspect?

title: RE: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: Why don't you use the semitones knob? This will change the pitch of osc2 that you want to maintain, but you can set this 12 semitones down in order to match with osc1 and then bring the whole program 1 octave up with the octave shift buttons.

title: RE: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: This will transpose the waves and shift their formants. Try it and you'll hear what I mean. Play a note with a multi sample, then shift down with semitones knob one octave and play one octave higher. You hear the same note as before but it does NOT sound the same. Now do the same with octave shift button, now it sounds the same. Problem is that OSC1 is shifted too with octave button so only solution I know is using separate slots which is a waste. Multisamples differ from ordinary oscillators in this respect.

title: RE: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: I haven't tried it with multisamples so I don't have a reason to doubt since you have tried it, I just thought it could work this way.I really can't understand why they made it such way that you can only pitch shift osc2 to osc1 and not vice versa. If there was the same wave options for both oscillators I could understand it, but some waves are available for only one of the oscillators, so there should be this option as well.

title: RE: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: As a last resort, you could "sample the sample" and then the other oscillator (independently) in Audacity, then mix them the way you wish, save them as a WAV file(s) and create a new nsmp file.

title: RE: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: As a last resort, you could "sample the sample" and then the other oscillator (independently) in Audacity, then mix them the way you wish, save them as a WAV file(s) and create a new nsmp file.That is a workaround if you want the sound to be the same all the time. If you want to introduce the second sound in some specific instances using any of the morphing sources, then you will have to sacrifice the second slot.

title: RE: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: I believe it's easier to change the root notes in the sample editor or use both slots. But still not very practical for such a simple task.

title: RE: Multisample combined with Osc1 in high octave?
post_content: I believe it's easier to change the root notes in the sample editorIf the sample is created by you and have access to the wav. files then that's the solution.Play a note with a multi sample, then shift down with semitones knob one octave and play one octave higher. You hear the same note as before but it does NOT sound the same.I guess it happens with all the samples, not only multisamples. There is a song we play with my band that is originally in the key of B but our singer is having a hard time with it so we decided to play it in the key of E instead. In order to practice at home playing over the original, I had to transpose 5 semitones down so that I can get used to the new finger position. The sound was indeed different than playing 5 semitones down without transposing. And it was more distinguishable when playing chords.

title: Managing samples question
post_content: HelloI am loving using the Wave but am new to it.I cannot fit all of the samples that I like into the (original) Wave due to memory capacity.  I can't seem to work out how to remove one sample set and load another entire set.  I have read the manual several times but can't work it out; maybe there is a limitation.  I also cannot load a folder just a file even though there is load a folder functionality.  I have latest firmware.The process seems to be that I need to download each individual sample to capacity each time and that is tedious.  Alternatively it seems that maybe if I load each set manually I could then do a backup and give that load a specific name to reflect the samples used.  Then I could have three of four different backups with unique samples.  So I just need to individually load the samples and do backups and restores.Have I understood this correctly?  Any tips please?Many thanksJupe

title: RE: Managing samples question
post_content: I find the Sound Manager works very well for managing all the uploading and downloading the sounds, individually or in selected groups or folders. The sounds are tied to programs and the bundle options helps with that issue. It shouldn't be too tedious. I will try and give some specific instructions and hope I'm not being tedious.To upload a selection of sounds to your computer:In Sound Manager make sure that Samp Lib (rather than program) is selected.Select the beginning of the group of sounds you want to upload to your computer by clicking on that sound.Scroll down to the bottom of the group of sounds, hit shift on your computer keyboard and then mouse click on that bottom sound.The group should now be highlighted in blue.Select Sound Up at the top of the Sound Manager. This will launch a box to confirm that you really do want to upload your group of sounds. Clicking Upload will launch another window allowing you to specify where you want those sounds to go.This is how it works on my Mac. I don't know about Windows anymore.Alternately you could just delete the sounds on your Wave2 and get more samples from the Nord web site.I would like to raise the question of why any of this being necessary at all. 1 GB is small these days and more memory in a Wave2 seems very realistic. There is something to be said for keeping the sample size small enough to be manageable and not just endlessly adding more and more, and we can get loads of sounds into 1 GB. Perhaps Nord will sell a Wave3 in the future with more memory and this is some marketing strategy, but I'd rather not think that way.

title: RE: Managing samples question
post_content: Thank you for your help and apologies for the delay in replying.  I hadn't realised that I had to select before uploading.  Have created a couple of banks and it works for uploading and downloading. Although it takes 15 minutes to do a download.  It seems quicker to load from a backup which is weird.  But at least it sounds good on the samples that I use.  It's curious that some samples from the Nord Sound Library sound great others flat and lifeless.  The stringsynth and Fairlight samples work well.I actually have the Wave and not Wave 2 and so the memory is very small.  Am not keen at all about the Wave 2 as it lacks fey features that I use on the Wave.  Nord are clearly in rush to do a Wave 3.

title: NW2 Half Pedaling?
post_content: Hello! First post - and probably a dumb questionDoes Nord Wave 2 support half-pedaling in any way?  If not, at what point (i.e. value 0-127) does CC64 trigger the sustain function on the NW2?Thanks so much!!!

title: RE: NW2 Half Pedaling?
post_content: Hi and welcome!nope, NW2 is a synth not a stage piano and half-pedaling is a technique which is peculiar of acoustic pianos and (some, not all) related specific sound engines.Usually the trigger for Sustain on is when CC64 value is >64 (but you can easily test it with a MIDI utility or a DAW, sending increasing values)

title: Control External Sound Modules Only on Certain Programs
post_content: Ok, so my intention is to set up a few of the live programs on the Wave 2 to control an external sound module. I do not want the module to be played on any other patches, just when I hit one of the live buttons; of course the Wave will have its layers turned down on those patches. In this way, I can switch between the Wave and the external module by simply hitting a button. Is there any reason why this would not work?I assume I would just set the individual channels of the layers on the live programs to be different than the default assignment, and have the sound module respond to only those channels. The manual says the channels can be assigned per patch, so it seems this would all be doable.Any thoughts?

title: Love for the Wave 2!
post_content: Greetings, I purchased a Wave 2 as my first Nord a few weeks ago. Though I got a great deal on a demo unit, It was still a lot of money for me, but I have to say - it was totally worth it.I have dabbled with various mono synths and a few polys in the past and I feel like the W2 is a revelation! On paper it was just what I was looking for, a performance instrument that can play some traditional keys or do some electronic stuff in a blink of an eye, something highly versatile. After getting it and living with it for a while, I really love it. It's so inspiring and clever the way it's laid out. The build quality is out of this world, are all Nords like this? If they are, I totally get why you see them on stages all over the place. Anyway, I'm not sure why it's not more popular. Maybe it's the lack of good demos or maybe the 'presets' (which I don't use) don't grab people, the price (though a used one is in the ball park of your Novations and Rolands)? I don't know.All I know is I'm a Nord convert! Thanks for having me!

title: RE: Love for the Wave 2!
RE: Love for the Wave 2!
post_content: welcome to the red community! Yes, all nords have the same build quality. They are handmade in a small factory, almost like a family company, and treated with care. I guess the wave2 is not so popular yet due to the lack of videos with custom sounds or from live performances (who gigs in those days?). All demo videos with preset patches show just the potentials, it's up to the users to show what this machine can do through their work. Also worth to mention that lots of other brands released new synths lately witch are all great and raise the competition.

title: RE: Love for the Wave 2!
post_content: I brought my new Wave 2 home October 2 and I've loved it ever since. It's my first Nord and my first hardware synth. I want to speculate why it's not more massively popular with the synthesizer community (despite being totally unqualified to do that). There are some obvious things we can't do with the wave2 like scanning through a set of waveforms in the wavetable, and loading and editing our own wave forms. And it seems we should have more control of the FM carrier/modulator configurations. While those things seem like deficiencies it really doesn't seem to limit the great sounds I can get out of my wave2. I kinda think those things make it easier to play and configure. Perhaps Nord is holding some good stuff back for a wave3. Perhaps some long time Nord users would know if Nord does stuff like that.

title: RE: Love for the Wave 2!
post_content: I suspect it is not as popular due to the limited LFO options and other simplifying decisions Nord made. The resale value on these seems to be lower than other Nords -- I paid $1900 for mine, mint. I ended up trading it for a Prophet6 because at least my unit had a bug that drove me nuts, but the tone was fantastic and despite some limitations it's far more flexible than it may first appear if you understand synthesis and can think outside of the box when programming. Naturally the P6 is easier to dial up a classic analog sound because it's all right there (no configs, multi layer etc) but it's far less flexible and in terms of raw tone between the 2, just on analog waves, the Nord was almost there...in a mix no one would know and even soloed it can be very close. I'd gladly own another one day and frankly often miss it but could not deal with the bug that at least my unit had.

title: RE: Love for the Wave 2!
post_content: Hey, thanks for the reply, the P6 is super sweet! One day...!Every synth has their limitations, that's for sure. Sometimes those limitations can be sources for creativity. Don't get me wrong, I still love breaking out the trusty moog and cranking the filter overdrive, but the W2 is also so inspiring to jam on it, it can get so deep so quick and back again. It's nice when a synth can go from tight snaps to massive reverb land with the turn of the wheel, with 4 simultaneous arps with different time divisions going around in crazy clockwork counter-rhythms! The tension on the mod stick reminds me of playing a guitar when bending, I like that you really have to dig into it a bit.Care to elaborate on bugs? I haven't encountered any issues thus far, my W2 has been solid.

title: RE: Love for the Wave 2!
post_content: For reference I did submit the bug to Nord, along with the vibrato sync mentioned above.The bug was the main LFO not syncing across layers just like the vibrato one, even when editing the LFO as a group or in multi-edit mode. I could not get it to consistently sync across multiple layers once a patch was saved and re-selected later. This made synth-style vibrato, at best, a guessing game as to whether it would behave correctly or not.I had posted about this on another forum, and DJ Keys had actually tested some stuff on this for me and could not replicate it. My hope is that it was only a bug with my unit somehow...An easy way to test, for those interested:1. Use 2 layers. Set both to the same sound, but for clarity I would put them an octave apart.2. Add both to the group for LFO editing, or use multi edit mode. Set the LFO however you like. For now, it should be in sync.3. Save patch, reload it later and see if it's still in sync. You can move to other patches and back again multiple times to confirm it is working.If unsure, slow the LFO rate down a lot and it will be very obvious if it is working or not because if out of sync the LFO's may  travel in opposite directions!

title: Morphing External Gear via MIDI?
post_content: I was looking at the MIDI CC list in the Wave2 manual and didn't see anything listed for performance controllers (minus pedal,) so this got me thinking. If you assign a morph to mod wheel and aftertouch, what do these performance controls send out? Do they actually send the morph CC's or generic mod wheel (cc1) and aftertouch data? If they send the morph CC's that are assigned to that controller, this could be a huge amount of fun in some situations I can think of.

title: RE: Morphing External Gear via MIDI?
post_content: tsss27 wrote:I was looking at the MIDI CC list in the Wave2 manual and didn't see anything listed for performance controllers (minus pedal,) so this got me thinking. If you assign a morph to mod wheel and aftertouch, what do these performance controls send out? Do they actually send the morph CC's or generic mod wheel (cc1) and aftertouch data? If they send the morph CC's that are assigned to that controller, this could be a huge amount of fun in some situations I can think of.They send out their original MIDI CC or message (MW=CC1, AT = Channel Pressure, which is not a CC), the morphing is handled only internally by the sound engine.PS: on the NordStage only you can still remap the CC that those controllers send out with a little trick, which involves using the Extern Section i.e. creating a (MW or AT or CtrlPed) morph on the Extern MIDI CC, which is freely assignable.

title: RE: Morphing External Gear via MIDI?
post_content: Thanks, that will still be fine, just thought it could be fun to remap but in reality I think sending default values is better.How is the velocity response of the Wave's keyboard when playing external gear? Internally it can be adjusted with morphing, but externally it seems there would just be one curve and no way to adjust it.To clarify, my use case is to pair the Wave2 with a GSI Gemini, as they compliment each other very well -- what one lacks, the other can do and each addresses the complaints I had with the other. I can use external MIDI gear to toggle sending of MIDI data to the Gemini, so that is not a problem, and the Gemini can have custom MIDI CC's mapped to the Nord's controls.

title: New Nord Wave 2 Sound Pack
post_content: Hi All,Just released my first sound pack for Nord Wave 2. A mixture of pads, plucks, basses, leads, arps etc. each of which only uses one wave 2 layer so you can layer and split them with each other or with your other sounds. A few are custom samples, but most use the NW2 internal sounds, so this pack doesn't use up much NW2 sample memory.The pack is available on Synthonia here:https://www.synthonia.com/marketplace/n ... nts-detailHere are a few demos of some of the sounds:Shimmer Pad:NW2 ShimmerPad.mp3A pad sampled via a 100% wet shimmer reverb. Works great layered with another pad - saves having to use a separate shimmer reverb pedal.Trance Lead / Trance Pluck / Trance PadNW2TranceLead_TrancePluck_TrancePad.mp3Big superwave trance sound as a lead, pluck or pad using just one layer.  Bigger than you can get using the NW2 internal supersaw sound.Mahoosive PadNW2 Mahoosive Pad.mp3Massive pad - good mix filler using only 1 layer.

title: RE: Wave Mod Wheel Problem (???halp)
post_content: Well, some time ago I got an original Wave again (I had one many years ago, sold it and always regretted it) and my god, this thing sounds SO good!The best synth Clavia ever produced IMHO (I never yet used the Wave 2, though).Anyway, I hadn't used it for a while and stored it vertically in its bag, resting on its side. Yesterday I got it out, and...the mod wheel isn't working anymore!I guess (and hope) it's only the usual mod wheel problem of Nords, it's much more common for the Stages (especially the infamous NS3 Compact WheelGate) but I saw that it happens sometimes to the Lead-Waves as well... hopefully it only needs tightening the pot screw and/or re-sitting the connector, as well documented in various places.nord-stage-forum-f3/nord-stage-3-sw73-m ... od%20wheelnord-stage-forum-f3/nord-stage-3-compac ... od%20wheelnord-stage-forum-f3/please-post-only-if ... ml#p125824I prefer to put all the links in one place for future reference, to avoid the proliferation of multiple threads on this recurrent subject.While we're at it, here's also another old thread I found, with very nice photos of the insides of the Wave where it's clearly seen that the mod wheel assembly is always the same among different Nord models.nord-wave-forum-f11/nord-wave-from-inside-t13797.htmlI'll open it up and let you know how it goes, just for the record. title: RE: Wave Mod Wheel Problem (???halp)
post_content: Just for the record, my Wave's mod wheel was not completely dead, only working intermittently.I opened the synth and it's really a super easy operation: just remove all the back screws and the two screws from the bottom panel holding the chassis (they're the only two "asymmetrical" screws, one under the left-hand controller and one in the power supply area; all the others are the screws holding the keybed assembly). Of the side screws, only remove the two front ones: the back ones can just be loosened a bit and will allow to open the chassis like a car's hood, without disassembling it completely: super easy, practical and without the risk of stretching-tearing the ribbon cables.On first inspection, nothing looked disconnected or out of place. Anyway, I loosened and re-set the screw holding the wheel to its potentiometer, and fixed in place the wheel wire connector with a drop of hot glue. Crossing fingers, the erratic behaviour is gone and my 10-plus years old Wave is working like new!

title: Wave 2 - Type of synthesis?
post_content: Hi - Stage 3 owner looking for my next thing. This is probably a stupid question, and maybe I'm just thrown off by the name "Wave", but does the Nord Wave 2 do the wavetable morphing/sequencing like a Waldorf or a  Hydrasynth or the Korg Wavestate?

title: RE: Wave 2 - Type of synthesis?
post_content: Hi-The NW2 does not support wave sequencing like the other boards you mention.  The Wavetables appear to be a collection of waves that can be used for any layer.  They are interesting but static.  You of course can morph between them, or morph Osc Control, filter or any other parameter for motion of the sounds, but true wavetable synthesis it is not--dj

title: Power on
post_content: I just read in my wave2 user manual (ch3 Getting Started) that I should power on my Nord before the sound system. Do you know what the issue is? I come from a time when "hot plugging" electronics into a live circuit was a bad thing to do. Can I damage my wave2 by powering it up after the connected amp (in my case a Focusrite audio interface)? It hasn't been a problem so far but I haven't yet connected it to a keyboard amp (some day).Thanks All

title: RE: Power on
post_content: Looks like I submitted this twice. Is there a way I can delete one of these postings?

title: RE: Power on
post_content: The only way to get one deleted is hitting the [!] triangle and report that post to a moderator.That "custom" is historic. Nothing new: Don't switch on a connected sound generator after having plugged the speakers - you could grill the speakers. It's not for the safety of the Wave2.

title: RE: Power on
post_content: powering on any audio device, (keyboard, mixer, etc) when connected to an active/powered on amplifier, is a good way to blow up your speakers. unless the equipment is specifically designed with a delayed output relay it can generate a significant output spike (usually associated with a very loud thump).

title: RE: Power on
post_content: 1) Set the synth volume to minimum.2) Set the amplification system level to minimum.3) turn on the synth.

title: RE: Power on
post_content: chris196 wrote:1) Set the synth volume to minimum.2) Set the amplification system level to minimum.3) turn on the synth.Setting the Synth Volume to minimum will not prevent the output from spiking when you turn on the power unless it is a passive control literally wired between the output stage of the synth and the physical output jack.On the Nord and most modern synths I don't believe this is the case as those controls are almost always programmable meaning they are not passive (which means they are electronically controlled and output buffer electronics will still spike when the power is turned on)turning the amplification system level to minimum is certainly a good idea.

title: RE: Power on
post_content: cgrafx wrote:chris196 wrote:1) Set the synth volume to minimum.2) Set the amplification system level to minimum.3) turn on the synth.Setting the Synth Volume to minimum will not prevent the output from spiking when you turn on the power unless it is a passive control literally wired between the output stage of the synth and the physical output jack.On the Nord and most modern synths I don't believe this is the case as those controls are almost always programmable meaning they are not passive (which means they are electronically controlled and output buffer electronics will still spike when the power is turned on)turning the amplification system level to minimum is certainly a good idea.Well you may be surprised but on Nord Stage the Master Volume is actually non programmable (only each Section volume is) and so is "passive", which may also be the case for the Wave 2.Then as you and most already said, in general and regardless the sound source, keeping amplification at minimum (and turning it on last) is the best way to stay on the safe side

title: RE: Power on
post_content: No matter what keyboard brand, no matter what PA or amps, no matter whether it‘s a large gig or a small venue - it has always been safe practise to switch on the chain from its head and to switch off the chain from its tail.And if the whole system is already on, then give the FOH girl or guy a signal to mute your channel for a moment.The reason for it all is just to avoid the loud „zack“ on the speakers.

title: RE: Power on
post_content: maxpiano wrote:cgrafx wrote:chris196 wrote:1) Set the synth volume to minimum.2) Set the amplification system level to minimum.3) turn on the synth.Setting the Synth Volume to minimum will not prevent the output from spiking when you turn on the power unless it is a passive control literally wired between the output stage of the synth and the physical output jack.On the Nord and most modern synths I don't believe this is the case as those controls are almost always programmable meaning they are not passive (which means they are electronically controlled and output buffer electronics will still spike when the power is turned on)turning the amplification system level to minimum is certainly a good idea.Well you may be surprised but on Nord Stage the Master Volume is actually non programmable (only each Section volume is) and so is "passive", which may also be the case for the Wave 2.Then as you and most already said, in general and regardless the sound source, keeping amplification at minimum (and turning it on last) is the best way to stay on the safe side  [emoji106]On the NS3 (and other nords), the master output is not just a simple potentiometer that analog sound is routed through, as far as I can tell.You are correct that it isn't programmable - as in you could potentially affect it via eg the wheel - but the output is not sent through the potentiometer at the end of the signal chain.So if something spikes when the unit boots up, you could get a spike sent to the PA even when volume is at 0.On the other hand, I think there is an output relay that normally prevents this from happening, so it's extremely unlikely to happen in practice. But if something is not working quite right in the nord, it could fry the speakers if you're really unlucky.Sent from my phone in brevity

I use them a lot. Can they be emulated better than the samples I find under -https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... -30/pianosLooking forward to get some advice here

title: RE: Need advice - Swap my Electro 5 for a new Nord Wave 2?
post_content: Regarding the superb synth, yes you get one when buing a wave2. However there are some restrictions compared to the lead series, such as LFO's. The leads have 2 LFO's x 4 layers + various destinations for each LFO, the wave has only one LFO per layer and fewer destinations. The leads do not support samples though...When it comes to organ and piano then you have to compromize with samples or wavetables as there are no dedicated piano and organ engines. You can have some acceptable tones with those samples but not as realistic as the piano and organ of your electro. There is no leslie simulation for organ, the only way is to fake it with an LFO.The best solution for you is to sell the electro and get a stage if you can afford it, if not then keep the electro and add a cheap synth on top, there are lots of good synths from other manufacturers in much lower price than the wave.

title: RE: Need advice - Swap my Electro 5 for a new Nord Wave 2?
post_content: The Rhodes and Wurlitzer samples (only one Wurli on board) can provide serviceable results, especially when combined with FM and effects like Chorus, Delay, and Pan.  As Alex mentioned, you will not get a B3 sound out of the wave. Cheesy Farfisa sounds are easy.  If you need good B3 sounds, get a Stage Compact. I actually did sample my NS2 B3 for an owner of the original Wave a few years ago, I have attached it. All drawbars at full, leslie slow with a little drive. I loaded into my NW2 and it sounds pretty good.  It is not looped properly, though, so you can't hold a note for more than 10 seconds. Should work for practice though. If I feel ambitious, i will sample my NS3 slow and fast (looped correctly this time), assign a sample to each layer, and morph between them--djNS2B3.nsmp(7.96 MiB) Downloaded 164 times

title: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: Does anyone have a workflow they recommend for sampling Virtual Instruments into the Sound Manager for their Wave 2?How many notes do you tend to sample? Do you same every note, or every other note? Any other tips?I want to give this a shot over the weekendthanks in advance!

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: Hi-When sampling instruments into the Nord Sample Editor, I find it best to sample about 10 notes or so about a third apart.  Make sure you put a space between all of the notes in a single .wav file. Keep the sample dry with no effects.  Once you have the .wav file with the 10 notes with spaces, just drop it into the SE and it will automatically map the notes and make the multi-sample for you.-dj

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: Absolutelly agree with DJkeys. I would also add that the more notes you record, the most accurate the sample will be. If you record every X notes the software will create the in between samples by "guessing" how those notes will sound. There might be very small differences from the original this way. The ideal is to record evey note, but the nsmp size will be be very big and occupy a lot of memory in your instrument. So every 3 notes is good choice IMO.

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: "A third apart" (3-4 semitones) and "every third" (3 semitones) is not the same - but both answers together would be my answer, too: Something between every 3rd and every 5th semitone - depending on the sound type and the quality desired. Maybe, you put them closer together in the middle of the keyboard (or wherever you play mostly). If you have a choice: My calimba/sanza only has 5 tones to record.

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: DJKeys wrote:Hi-When sampling instruments into the Nord Sample Editor, I find it best to sample about 10 notes or so about a third apart.  Make sure you put a space between all of the notes in a single .wav file. Keep the sample dry with no effects. Seems like there are 3 or 4 notes from every octave.

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: I’ve been recording samples of about a second or so for every key on the keyboardA second is very short, even for a plucked type of sound. Especially when the original sound has a long attcak or some evolving texture you will need much more than that. in just one second the sounds envelope has not been fully developed. You should record a few seconds more after it reaches to the sustain level, you will have some "body" to loop then. Instead of recording every key with short duration, It's better to sample fewer but with longer duration IMO, try every 3rd semitone.

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: Thanks for your interest, DJ.I am recording into GarageBand on a MacBook Pro. title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: Why don't you just record directly into Logic and then export that recording as a .wav file?  Why use Garage Band at all? I would eliminate Garage Band and the USB transfer, you are going through a lot of unnecessary conversions in my opinion. I think you would obtain better results if you:Set up a stereo track in LogicSelect the Moog stereo pair in the Focusrite for the input.press record, play every third semitone for a few seconds with a couple of seconds of space between it.Stop record, trim the beginning and end of the file.Export the track as a .wav file.Drop that file into NSE3.-dj

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: alex78 wrote:Still, what I’ve done hasn’t seemed enough to get a dependable sustain to loop, especially in the high register that has faster beats with the notes’ imperfections. I should try much longer recordings.What I suspect is that you probably let the Sample editor apply the loop without fine tuning the start and end points yourself. I admit I spend a lot of time with each idividual note in order to adjust the loop points so that the beats are not audible.Here is a video about the sample editor, at about 7:30 he is showing how to adjust the loops. Hope it helps.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eLiaEF4Jhw0I look forward to studying the video you gave for help. I spent a lot of time fine tuning the start and end points of each note's loop, but I think my problem was the original tone had a couple oscillators which were slightly detuned, and they added some natural beating between oscillators. This became faster in duration the higher the pitch. This wouldn't be a noticeable problem playing on the Voyager itself, but when translated to a sample it made it problematic finding a loop point that didn't seem like an unnatural lfo cycling back, if that makes sense. And maybe I should have used the whole duration minus the cutoff.So, I think recording much longer samples might help, or eliminating the detune or even adjusting the detune up the scale to keep the pitch beating more manageable as pitch increases. In some ways, the end result worked out okay and provided some variation that almost mimics envelope or lfo variation that might occur in a vintage instrument.And thanks! Your collective suggestions have helped to process the situation.

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: We are glad to help.  And, it is a good idea to record the samples with no detuning or any other effects.  Just the raw sound to be processed later in the NW2.-dj

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: The other idea I just had is to upload separate instances of one oscillator to layers of the Wave 2 and fine tune the detuning in the instrument. This will solve any detuning beat issues, as you suggest, and possibly provide interesting results with detuning sampled patches through layering.

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: That is an excellent idea!-dj

title: RE: Sampling Virtual Instruments workflow?
post_content: Unfortunatelly there are not so many videos available regarding the sample creation. All of them show the very basics and they usually use simple sounds. When the original sound has complicated textures it's very difficult to achieve a really good sounding sample, that will sustain without gaps I mean. Aslo I have a feeling that the new sample editor is more automated in order to make things easier for the user but with the old one you could tweak more things, I may be wrong though...I've never used the new. In any case, a sample is always a sample and can never replace the real thing.

title: M4L - Free Nord Bank/Patch Control for the Wave 2
post_content: I wanted a way to sequence program changes easily in Ableton Live and the bank/patch organization in the Wave 2 is weird (Midi banks A-E are midi bank 1, F-J are bank 2, sequenced programs are in groups of five by five from 11-15, 21-25...etc.)So I banged up a simple control in M4L you can drag into your Ableton Library to control/sequence program changes a bit more easily.It's free. title: Sample Library compatibility ...?
post_content: 1. Does nord wave 2 read the library:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... library-202. Does nord wave 2 read patches of Nord Stage (synth patches)?

title: RE: Sample Library compatibility ...?
post_content: RafalSC wrote:1. Does nord wave 2 read the library:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... library-202. Does nord wave 2 read patches of Nord Stage (synth patches)?1. No - NW2 uses the Nord Sample Library 3.0https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... library-302. No - generally Nord program files are incompatible between different Nord models, and even different versions of the same model, e.g. Stage 2 and 3.I use both the Stage 3 and NW2 and while there is some commonality between the Stage 3 synth and Wave 2, there are also significant differences.  You can get a lot of the same sounds by using similar settings (although to my ears the Wave 2 filter seems more closed than the Stage 3 - seems to need a higher cut off on Wave 2 for the same sound).  There are some features unique to each that mean you need to do things differently to get the same (or at least similar) sound.

title: RE: Sample Library compatibility ...?
post_content: RafalSC wrote:1. Does nord wave 2 read the library:https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... library-202. Does nord wave 2 read patches of Nord Stage (synth patches)?1. Yes, not natively but Nord Sound Manager will automatically convert the sample to v3 when downloading a .nsmp v1/v2 to NW22. No, as hoopyfrood said each Nord keyboard is usually only compatible with itself (including the EX version, if existing)

Am i wrong to assume that?Also, it seems to me that on certain accounts it lost some of the oscillator configurations that the NS3 offers. For example the ringmod is one obvious example.

post_content: frama78 wrote:Another question: do the basic samples of the Lib3 sound the same on different Nords (NE6, S3, W2...)?They should (if you mean really the bare sample, no filter or envelope or dynamics or anything else set, i.e. with .nsmp v3 you need to ignore/zero the preset values which may be included in the v3 file format), of course apart from minimal differences determined by each model's analog output stage (DAC->OpAmps & related)

title: Wave 2 Arp Sync Issues When Sequenced
post_content: alright so im at a total loss here. I have the wave 2 and i can sync the arp to an external midi clock only when hold is enabled. my problem starts when i want to  sequence the arpeggiator. id prefer not to have it constantly running and only arpeggiate when the sequencer is sending note data (like held chords but sequenced). it works fine as long as hold is enabled but once hold is removed it drifts all over the place is makes a giant mess. has anyone had rbis issue? my virus handles this just fine, so does my novation ultranova, peak and hydrasynth. pretty much going to send it back if it cant be resolved.

title: RE: Wave 2 Arp Sync Issues When Sequenced
post_content: Are you sending sequence data on the global channel?  The ARP is per layer, so you will want to have a program that is in midi layer mode where each layer has its own midi channel (disable the Global midi channel).  This is stored per program. You can sequence more than one layer by grouping the ARPs associated to them. Also, the NW2 receives master clock data on CC 68. Any details on your setup would be helpful--dj

title: RE: Wave 2 Arp Sync Issues When Sequenced
post_content: DJKeys wrote:Are you sending sequence data on the global channel?  The ARP is per layer, so you will want to have a program that is in midi layer mode where each layer has its own midi channel (disable the Global midi channel).  This is stored per program. You can sequence more than one layer by grouping the ARPs associated to them. Also, the NW2 receives master clock data on CC 68. Any details on your setup would be helpful--djthanks for your response. this is confusing.Im sending sequencer data from Global Slot 1 of my Analog Four to Global Slot 1 of the NW2. The A4 is sending date from Track 1 / Channel 1 and is going into the NW2 set to receive it on Midi Channel 1. The data includes note, note length, note velocity as well as the incoming midi clock. If I sequence notes on their own it's not an issue, but once I start involving the NW2s time-based features (ARP, LFO, FX) its a literal disaster. I can get the ARP to sync when it's just receiving incoming MIDI clock data and Im playing the notes manually by hand. But if I try to send those notes via MIDI all bets are off. I've never had an issue like this with any of my other devices, including Nord Leads. I have a Cirklon Sequencer and that can't get it to stick either. I'm afraid this is begging to be more work than its worth at this point.

title: RE: Wave 2 Arp Sync Issues When Sequenced
post_content: Well, if you still want to at least find out what might be happening, I would suggest scaling the problem to its basic elements. If there is some sort of issue with the NW2, you can find out for sure. Make sure you have the latest build, 1.16 loaded on the Wave2:1. Set up an empty patch on the NW2. That will give you a saw wave on Layer 1 with layers 2-4 disabled.2.  In the Midi menu, set global to off and program Layer 1 for midi channel 1 and save the program.3. With the Arp disabled, send your sequence from a single device to the NW2 and note the response.4. Enable the Arp, send the sequence again and note the response.This should determine if the NW2 is correctly responding to the sequence data.  Remember, the Arp is per layer unless you group it to control multiple layers.-dj

title: Nord Wave FM question
post_content: On my NS3 when i choose FM, i get control over the amount of FM and also control over the pitch of the modulator.I read the user manual of the Wave 2 and noticed that there are more FM algorithms etc. But, when it comes to control i only found something written about using the OSC control for setting the amount of FM, but didn't see anything mentioned about the controlling the pitch of the modulator.Is there an option to do that? Seems trivial but i'm asking since i didn't see this mentioned in the manual.

title: RE: Nord Wave FM question
post_content: I don't have the Wave 2 and am NOT an expert/that much interested in synthesizers, so take what I'll say with a pinch of salt. The only things I know, I have been discovering them since when I got a reface DX (which I love!), and reading stuff online. And what I have noticed so far is that there seems to be a fair amount of confusion and vagueness, on the internet, around how FM works. I am not sure if that's because it is too complex for the layman to grasp, or because there simply is a lot of confusion around something that could be explained more clearly but for some reason isn't. Or it could be a mix of both.It seems that the very basic, yet theoretical, thing that's unclear is the very two variables FM works with.According to the way I have understood it so far, and nothing else, those variables are:- FM frequency, which is thespeedyou basically apply vibrato to a pitch with,- FM amount, which is actually therangeof that vibrato, up and down by the same amount (for linear FM at least).This is no different than pitch bending a note with the pitch bend stick within a given range, except that our arms can only move as fast as "a few" oscillations per second, which will result in just... well, vibrato. When that bending speed becomes way higher and approaches similar frequencies of the ones of the very note you are pitch-bending, though, "interesting" (or perhaps "unpredictable") results start to appear. You cease to hear, say, Ab-A-A#-A-Ab-A-..., or G-A-B-A-G-A-...; instead you'll hear just A but with a lot of harmonics.Now, it seems to me that most FM synthesizers do two things:- They tell you FM "frequency" in various ways, but generally as aratiobetween the modulator and the pitch you are FM-ising, for example "twice the frequency", "a quarter the frequency", and the like;- They DON'T explicitly tell you therangeof this super fast vibrato you're applying. Instead, they have sliders (physical or virtual) that let you set the FM "amount". Whether that's going to be in the range of microtones, semitones, tones, octaves, or the universe knows, I have no idea.The Synth on the NS3 does the first of those things in a way that in my opinion is even more convenient of the traditional "ratio" way, that is, it tells you how many semitones away that frequency will turn out to be from the pitch being FM-ised, which is more handy. But regarding the second thing, you simply have a knob which, once again, doesn't tell you how many semitones you are making that vibrato range expanding to and from.Now, I don't know the Wave 2, but if we want to use the language I've employed in this post, so far, you are saying that the Wave 2 doesn't have a control for vibrato speed, but only for vibrato range -- albeit we don't still have a clue about how big that would be in semitones.Is all the above fair? Aren't you sure the "speed" parameter isn't hidden somewhere else under another menu, possibly called in a different way?EDIT: I am aware that knowing that value, in semitones, wouldn't be useful since the only thing we care of is the final sound. But still, it would be nice to at least know for a fact that that's the parameter being modified, and by how much.EDIT 2: The fact that the same effect of FM is achievable via Phase shifting, and therefore that this is what's really going on under the hood of a "FM" synthesizer, doesn't in my view change a thing about the need to know exactly how the parameters are being affected.

title: RE: Nord Wave FM question
post_content: I think you got it right. Semitone units make sense for LFOs/vibrato when the value of the modulation amplitude is static (i.e. you reach those extreme values in every cycle of the modulation), but not so intuitive for FM synthesis as (most often) it does not use a fixed modulation amplitude, but it is governed by EGs and sometimes a chain of modulators.These are quite good, perhaps you've seen them:https://www.soundonsound.com/techniques ... modulationhttps://www.soundonsound.com/techniques ... modulationThe Nord FM engines are a nice thing to have, but they are quite simplistic when compared to current FM synths like the MODX/Montage.

title: RE: Nord Wave FM question
post_content: zahush76 wrote:I read the user manual of the Wave 2 and noticed that there are more FM algorithms etc. But, when it comes to control i only found something written about using the OSC control for setting the amount of FM, but didn't see anything mentioned about the controlling the pitch of the modulator.I think the ratio of frequencies is fixed for each algorithm and you can control the amount of modulation (Level in DX speak) via OSC CTRL (Page 21 of the NW2 manual).

title: RE: Nord Wave FM question
post_content: Mr_-G- wrote:These are quite good, perhaps you've seen them:https://www.soundonsound.com/techniques ... modulationhttps://www.soundonsound.com/techniques ... modulation.Thanks. I did run into them but didn't look very thoroughly. Seemed too complex for my level, but I guess it's time to dive in.This is not the appropriate place to talk FM, I guess, but my main beef with FM so far would be that it isn't so much about it being difficult, but rather it being *unpredictable*, and therefore, of lesser use than something less capable in theory but much more straightforward in practice.Even the very basic principle FM works by, namely the fact that once the vibrato oscillation speed approaches audible frequencies, we cease to hear vibrato but instead we hear the same note with a higher harmonics content, isn't THAT predictable to me. I mean it took FM to find that out, it wasn't predictable before. Now we kind of accept it for granted. Conversely, if I apply a low pass filter to a wave, I can pretty much anticipate what's going to happen, and I can thus build my sound the way I want it.With FM, when more complex setups are employed (a chain of modulators), then it seems to me the level of unpredictability goes so high that it becomes a sort of trial and error until you get, almost by chance, the sound you need. And all of this only when using modulators frequencies which are equal to the pitch of the carrier, or an octave or a fifth away. If the frequency ratio is some non round number such as 1,354, then the only results I have been getting are akin to pure noise...Of course I am exaggerating, but this was to give a layman impression.

title: RE: Nord Wave FM question
post_content: To me it is not so much the "unpredictability", but the "unintuitive" nature of the FM oscillator/algorithms. I do not think you are alone, virtually everybody struggles with FM despite that it can generate some incredible sounds.

title: RE: Nord Wave FM question
post_content: Yeah, that's probably a language mismatch but I did mean precisely that. So far it seems to me more of a physics/acoustic curiosity than an actually useful mean to create sounds. Nevertheless, I do enjoy trying.

title: Problem with osc mod env
post_content: Guys I have problem with osc mod envelop. When I choose osc pitch and set amount on -0,2 or 0,2 I have big drift pith this osc to other osc without mod env. Maybe it's bug. Please check on your NW 2.

title: RE: Problem with osc mod env
post_content: I just tried this on an Init patch - I'm not seeing any unexpected behaviour. I enabled two layers, dialled one with 0.2 osc mod pitch amount (and I also tried other amounts), and the other with none. I get a little expected pitch movement on the modulated layer, as per the envelope settings, and then it settles back to being perfectly in tune with the 0.0 layer.But... the Osc Mod Env has the AR (Attack/Release) mode as well, and that works a different way. For the default AD (Attack/Decay) mode, modulated pitch deviates from 0 (in tune) during the attack phase, and goes back to it in the decay phase. Notes start and finish bang in tune, as long as the osc mod envelope has enough time to complete its whole cycle. However, if you have it in AR mode then the attack phase brings the noteintotune - where it sits for the sustain portion (it really should be called an 'ASR') - and then pulls it back out again when the key is released and the envelope release phase triggers. So notes essentially begin and end out of tune. I wonder if it's that you're hearing. It certainly can make for some super-wonky tuning if you have amp release time set quite long. It would obviously do it with any envelope amount though, not just 0.2.This is on the latest 1.14 OS, btw.

title: Osc control knob - NW2 vs NS3, what you gain what you lose
post_content: Been digging deeper on my NS3 synth engine and was wondering (and perhaps a bit confused) after going thru the Wave 2 user manual.I understand there are certain parameters which have been removed from the Wave 2 as there are dedicated knobs for that - such as tuning of the oscillator.Things that i see which are different, and at least at first sight seem like a step back on the Wave 2 are for example the oscillator sync, which on the Stage 3 works on the analog categories, and also the "wave" categories and "formant" waves category.On the Wave 2 it seems you have a set of waves dedicated just for sync sounds - but at the same time you lose the ability to apply sync to almost all waveshapes - which behave differently.Also different are some categories of "mixed waves" that you can find on the NS3 which are very useful. Stuff such as a regular waveform plus a bell or a noise etc - where you can tune the additional sound and use the osc control to determine the amount of mix between the two. This also works for samples so you can do some cool mixtures of acoustic sounds and noise or acoustic sounds and saw/sqr/tri etc.  All of this is gone from the Wave 2 algorithms, me thinks (unless i'm missing something).Also, fm and waveshape could be applied on the NS3 on all the first 3 categories (analog, waves, formant). Not so on the Wave 2.And finally, "ring modulation" (not as an fx) could be applied on the NS3 on all the waves from 'analog', 'waves', 'formant' - and also the samples.Both ringmod and shape modulation are missing from the Wave 2 when it comes to the digital waves which on the NS3 can change their tone but on the Wave 2 remain static and you can't change their shape, sync or fm them.What, to my understanding, you gain on the Wave 2 engine - is a dedicated tune and fine tune knobs, multiwaves, a more complex FM engine.Did i miss anything?If i'm mistaken or completely missed how the osc section on the Wave 2 works then please correct me.

post_content: I am a relatively new owner of the Nord Wave 2. I also own an A1 and a Nord Stage Compact 3. The keybed is outstanding. I'm most appreciative of how good it is and it is a huge upgrade over both the A1 and the Stage Compact for my purposes.The patches are mostly there to get you started. They are instructional more than anything. With the A1 there were some outstanding libraries added later. Some of that has already happened with the Wave 2, and here's hoping there will be more.Nord patches are never flashy as much as instructional and a means to get you started. Indeed, on the NW2 there are at least 50 (of the 400) that are outstanding. The rest are just basic structures. But even those are useful. The acoustic guitar patch, for example, has a lovely delay when you turn the wheel. Layer 2 has some FM to give it body and ballast. On Layer three I added a cello to provide a drone. That's enough.The NW2 has taken some critical hits from advanced synthesists and I'm sure some of their criticisms are justified. But for quick access, seamless operating system, and an easy way to blend samples, analog, FM, and Wavetables, it's terrific.I, for one, am absolutely satisfied.

title: RE: Please offer Wave 2 with faster key bed & better patches
post_content: I have never understood disappointment in the factory patches.  I erased 75% of them as soon as got the keyboard, the ones I kept so I could figure out "how did they do that?". If you are buying a board to just play presets then Nord is the wrong choice.  When I began my programming (I needed about 70 programs) I realized how easy it was to get the sounds I needed.  The capabilities of this instrument are amazing, and I have created a number of programs already, just for fun, which show how flexible the NW2 is.  Plus, I also think the keybed is great.  It has about 2mm less throw than my NS3C and a much deeper after touch bed for really expressive playing.  This is truly 4 synths in box built like a tank that weighs less than 20 pounds.As you can tell, I like the NW2 a lot!-dj

title: RE: How many parameters can be assigned to one morph source?
post_content: I don't think there is a limit, but haven't tested it, and have no reason to use more than a few at once.What would you want to accomplish by morphing 30 parameters at once, assuming that is possible?-dj

title: RE: How many parameters can be assigned to one morph source?
post_content: DJKeys wrote:I don't think there is a limit, but haven't tested it, and have no reason to use more than a few at once.What would you want to accomplish by morphing 30 parameters at once, assuming that is possible?-djThat's like asking why would you need 32 mod slots on the Hydrasynth.I imagine that not all morphing should be extreme. Subtle changes to several parameters to achieve pleasing results.So it's mostly a question of information. If you could test that, i'd appreciate it very much.I'm trying to make up my mind between the NW2 and the Novation Summit. The Summit has a mod matrix (and an additional mod matrix dedicated just for the fx section). That's deep. Not to mention the analog filters.But setting up modulation invloves menu diving, there are less options in the osc section (except it has real wavetables and not just single cycle waves).But to me, in lot of cases it makes more sense to have a morph type of modulation than a constant type of modulation. title: RE: How many parameters can be assigned to one morph source?
post_content: OK, you are talking about NW2.The manual says that you can control "several" parametres with one morph source. And you can delete not only all morphs at once, but also one parametre by one. There is no limit mentioned - but you might ask Nord directly.Edit: I'd assume there is no matrix or grid that can be full but rather real time calculating power might be used up at a certain moment, depending on the effects you are using.
