title: How do "Grouping" works?
post_content: I don't have the wave 2 yet, and was wondering. I see you can group layers together completely - or decide just on certain aspects to be grouped. For example on the front panel i see you can decide you group the Filter for some layers (let's say all 4 for the sake of discussion) but can decide not to group the lfos.So...  will this give me one filter affecting all 4 layers at once - while having 4 independant lfos which i can use together on the same filter to create interesting/complex sounds of it being modulated by 4 different lfos, each with a different shape and rate?

title: RE: How do "Grouping" works?
post_content: Hi Z-Yes, this is exactly how it works. You can group all four layers to have filter cutoff morphed by the wheel, for example, and also have each layer separately affected by the LFO parameters including wave shape, rate and amount. You can also pan each layer at different places in the stereo field, and apply other different FX to each layer for even more variety.-dj

title: RE: How do "Grouping" works?
post_content: DJKeys wrote:Hi Z-Yes, this is exactly how it works. You can group all four layers to have filter cutoff morphed by the wheel, for example, and also have each layer separately affected by the LFO parameters including wave shape, rate and amount. You can also pan each layer at different places in the stereo field, and apply other different FX to each layer for even more variety.-djThanks, but i think you're describing a different scenario than what i meant.I'm asking about a scenario in which only the filter is shared by all 4 layers while keeping everything else independant.In a scenario like this do i get "one filter to rule them all", while using all 4 different lfos to modulate the one filter, each with its different rate and shape?Can it be turned, basically, to a one layer synth with one filter and four lfos being able to modulate it?

title: RE: How do "Grouping" works?
post_content: Well, I am not sure we are saying something different, so perhaps my explanation could be better.  When the filter is grouped for all four layers, each LFO can indeed be used to modulate that grouped filter in a different way.  I just tested this. So, all layers share the same filter settings, and those settings can be modulated with a different LFO treatment for each layer. In addition, all other effects are also independent per layer, unless you group them as well. Any setting that is not grouped remains independent per layer.-dj

title: RE: How do "Grouping" works?
post_content: DJKeys wrote:Well, I am not sure we are saying something different, so perhaps my explanation could be better.  When the filter is grouped for all four layers, each LFO can indeed be used to modulate that grouped filter in a different way.  I just tested this. So, all layers share the same filter settings, and those settings can be modulated with a different LFO treatment for each layer. In addition, all other effects are also independent per layer, unless you group them as well. Any setting that is not grouped remains independent per layer.-djStill uncertain if we're describing the same thing.I'm thinking that "group" four layers and share the same filter - should be like a synth that has 4 osc, 4 lfos etc, but one main filter.When you write that "all layers share the same filter settings, and those settings can be modulated with a different LFO treatment for each layer" - shounds to me that you hear 4 copies of the same filter, each being modulated differently, which is not what i meant.For the sake of comparison take a prophet rev 2 which has 4 lfos. You can decide you route all four lfo to the filter, each with a different rate to create complex movement or rhythmic movement which is the result of one filter being modulated by 4 independent lfos.On the wave 2, it seems (correct me if i'm wrong), what you describe is that if you choose a 24db lowpass filter and group all layers, when you modulate the filter with each lfo what you hear is the sound of the filter on layer 1, plus the sound of the filter on layer 2, plus the sound of the filter on layer 3 plus the sound of the filter on layer 4. They all happen to be the same filter type - but it's not the same sonic result as having one filter being modulated by 4 lfos.But perhaps i misunderstood. Can you post an audio example?

title: RE: How do "Grouping" works?
post_content: There definitely was a misunderstanding here. As I mentioned on GearSlutz, you cannot use 4 different LFOs to modulate all layers simultaneously.  Each LFO can only modulate its own layer in the shared filter settings, which is what I mentioned earlier.However, I do not find this much of a limitation for the music I make.  If you are doing advanced sound design or film scoring, this may be something you need.-dj

title: NW2 - piano library loading ...?
post_content: I have this question - can I upload a piano sound to the NW2?https://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... no-library

title: RE: NW2 - piano library loading ...?
post_content: Quick answer: no, only NS, NP and NE can.Longer answer: there is no Piano section on NW2 so no Nord Piano library compatibility (see also Nord Piano library Information page for the list of compatible models), but you can load the Pianos of the Nord Sample libraryhttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... -30/pianos(of course these are monolayer, as all the .nsmp  samples, so don't expect to get the same + choice is much more limited).

title: RE: NW2 - piano library loading ...?
post_content: If you did not like the NP4 sounds as you mentioned in you other post, perhaps you might not have spent enough time tweaking the various settings, EQ, etc. or used a sub-optimal amp?I doubt very much that you will like the nsmp piano libraries in a NW2, as they are single layer samples and lack the relation between harmonic content and dynamics of the piano library, like maxpiano explained. The NW2 also has less polyphony (48 vs 120) than the NP4.

title: RE: NW2 - piano library loading ...?
post_content: As I have mentioned to other posts, you can not have everything at it's best quality in one board. You sacrifice something depending to your needs. The wave is a synth, so if you need piano or organ you have to compromize with samples or wavetables. If your most important sound is piano then you get a Nord Grand or Nord Piano, but forget about the synth. If you need everything in one portable pacage get the stage, but live with the fact that there will be some small limitations in every section compared to each individual instrument designed especially for the specific sounds.

title: 4-way Velocity Splits
post_content: Does anyone have any audio examples of patches, either preset or custom, that use all 4 layers with samples crossfaded by velocity? I know this is actually possible but I am curious to hear how well it works in practice with 4 layers, because it seems it would be difficult to dial them all in. Most seem to only crossfade 2 layers, if any.

title: RE: 4-way Velocity Splits
post_content: Good question

title: RE: 4-way Velocity Splits
post_content: I have experimented with this and can confirm that you can use the velocity splits, and that they are granular enough to have four of them.  If your desire is to have four samples of the same instrument at differing volumes, you would need to very carefully prepare four samples in advance, and the transitions between them really would not compete with a multi-sampled instrument. Plus, four samples is really not that many for a true multi-instrument in my opinion. There are no presets I have found that use this feature, most of the layer morphs are programmed with the mod wheel.What is it you would want to accomplish using this feature?-dj

title: RE: 4-way Velocity Splits
post_content: As you say, my desire is to have 4 samples of the same instrument, say a 4 layer piano, marimba, whatever. In this way, the Wave2 could double as a basic ROMpler for times when things need to be compact. Since many workstations from even a decade ago had only 4 velocity layers, I think it could provide for some expressive sounds given that you can still affect all the filter frequencies with the Nord among other things.Essentially it is a way to use custom multisampled instruments on the Nord, since we cannot create piano ones (and the Wave doesn't use those anyway.)

title: RE: 4-way Velocity Splits
post_content: I am not sure the transitions from layer to layer would be smooth enough to accomplish that. Plus, you would eat up a lot of the sample memory trying to multisample a Piano, for example.Not sure the effort involved would justify the result.  Do you own the instrument?  If so, try creating a few multisamples and let us know how it works.If not, I suggest the NW2 would not be a wise choice if this single feature is very important to you--dj

title: Meh
post_content: Good morning all,I have had my Wave 2 since they were released in the US a few months back.  I got one of the original units from Kraft with OS .8 on it.  Initially I was fairly excited by it after watching the couple of demos that were out there, but I feel like I get a lot more out of my A1 and Stage 3's than I do out of my Wave2.  I really love my Nords and want to love the Wave 2 and put it in my setup (usually run a NS3/NS3 or A1/NS3) but I feel like I have to put some work in to get better at programming it.Do you have any recommendations of videos etc that will help me wrap my brain around both what the unit is capable of and some of the programming stuff?

title: RE: Meh
post_content: I have a similar setup—Nord Stage 3 Compact and Nord Lead A1. I assumed that the Nord Wave 2 would be somewhat redundant but I figured I would eventually replace the A1. You have many more synths than I do, so I don't intend this as advice as much as an opportunity to discuss how I'm using the Wave 2 in my early days with it. I hope other users also discuss how they are exploring the instrument. I've been exploring the Wave 2 for a few weeks now. At first I was underwhelmed by the presets, but then I made a conceptual switch and began to look at the presets as instructional rather than a great library for personal use. However, there are some great presets, and some with interesting hidden features. One way I'm understanding how the Wave 2 works is by studying my favorite presets. Another approach is finding programs I most like on the Nord Stage 3 and the A1 and then reproducing them on the Wave 2. Obviously you can't do that with the pianos, organs, and clavs on the Compact 3, but you can for pretty much everything else. On the A1, the only thing (I believe) that you can't reproduce are the formant waves, but they are less important as there are so many great vocal samples on the Wave 2. Having said all of that, I have not yet begun to do what I suggest, leaving it, I suppose as a winter activity. What I have done is modify many of the presets, and then experiment with the samples. For me, the best feature of the Wave 2 is the ability to seamlessly layer four different samples, or to mix them with FM (something you can't really do with the other instruments). The two best features of the wave are (1) the fantastic layering-oriented interface (2) the rich mix of virtual analog, FM. Wavetable, and samples. I've been taking an experimental approach to sound design, flipping the knobs, seeing what happens, and learning from that. I think the most challenging learning curve is understanding how to integrate the arpeggiator with the delays, syncing them so as to create dynamic movement possibilities. A hands-on video of that process would be invaluable. Also, the A1 especially had a terrific online library fo sound design possibilities and it would be great to eventually see that for the Wave 2. In the meantime, I'm enjoying the purity of the sound.

title: RE: Meh
post_content: When I first got the NW2, I still had my A1 and used it for a couple of weeks as a guide for programming the sounds I needed. The NW2 is similar to the A1, but much more powerful, in my opinion. I erased all but about 100 sounds (kept the ones that I could learn a lot about the instrument from how they were made) and, using the A1 as my guide, programmed about 70 patches from scratch. The NW2 is easy to program coming from the A1, and has the added flexibility of samples.  In my experience, you cannot  accurately judge  the power of a keyboard by its presets.  Iactually like the keybed.  It is solid and has less throw than my NS3. The A1 keybed was much lighter (as was the NL4), and had no aftertouch.-dj

I did some playing around with creation on the NS3 synth, the Wave and the A1.  The NS3 actually killed them both because of some of the effects available for it, however I know there is a way to make something just as killer on the Wave if I put the time and energy into it.

YouTube has some but not one that goes through each and every function.Thanks so much for the help!Lastly, do you recommend an NW2? Mostly will composeThanks again

title: RE: Question on NW2 selecting programs
post_content: Hi, Jfish-A, B, C and D are not programs, they are layers.  All four layers are part of a  single program.  You can change the program using the program dial above the left OLED display.  All you have to do to change the sound of a layer is select that layer (its LED will blink) and make the changes you want. Those changes are made using the two knobs in the Oscillator section. One selects the type, the other selects the waveform under that category. In addition you can hit the Solo button and select a layer to hear only that layer while editing.You have to read the manual in detail and go through each step on the keyboard while reading so that you can understand the Nord Architecture.  It is  completely different from all of the other workstation UIs from Roland, Korg, Yamaha, etc.I think the NW2 will serve your purposes.  Once you understand the UI, you will see how simple it actually is--dh

title: RE: Question on NW2 selecting programs

title: Poly Mod Morph question
post_content: Poly Mod Morph question. As many of you will know the good old Prophet 5 and indeed the DSI Prophet 6 have a section called Poly Mod. This differs from ordinary modulation in that both its modulation sources and destinations are associated with one specific voice/note. e.g. modulating a voice’s oscillator with its own filter envelope, or a voice’s filter cutoff with the velocity associated with its assigned note. These are examples of poly modulation because they only effect one voice.  Whereas for example, channel aftertouch and mod wheel modulations are expected to effect all the voices of that layer according to the morph and hardwired assignments of the program – sometimes called channel mod.Morph mod sources on the NW2 include velocity, wheel, pedal and aftertouch. Of these only velocity is a polymod source.So my questions: -1. If I apply velocity through a morph to filter frequency is this a polymod modulation ie effecting only the voice to which the velocity is assigned, or does it effect all voices playing?2. It's possible to use a layer’s morph velocity assignment to turn down (or off!) the layer’s output for higher velocities BUT, does this effect all voices playing on that layer or only the one to which the velocity is assigned. Ie is this a polymod control.

title: RE: Poly Mod Morph question
post_content: Hey Hector-I thought the answer to #1 was that the morph is per layer and affects all notes played.  So I tested #2 and confirmed that you can indeed set up a morph to decrease a layer's output to 0 (with full velocity) but it affects all notes played.-dj

title: RE: Poly Mod Morph question
post_content: Hm... I'm not sure if I understand either of you correctly, but:0) All morphs are applied to notes in the particular layer only. So you can seamlessly transition from a layer A sound to layer B by setting up two morphs from 0 to 10 and from 10 to 0 respectively on velocity )or any other morphs).1) If I apply velocity morph to a filter frequency, each note played will sound with the morph value derived from its own velocity. Hence, if I play two notes at different velocity on a layer where I velocity morph from 220 Hz to 32 kHz, the lowest velocity note (MIDI 1) will sound with filter frequency 220 Hz and the higher velocity note (MIDI 127) with the filter fully open.2) I'm not sure if I understand the question correctly, but any note played with a velocity morphed output (modulated from 10 to 0, e.g.) will play at the output level corresponding to its velocity. So again, playing two notes in that layer at low and high velocities will mean that the low velocity layer will sound loud (or at full output) and the high velocity layer at lowest amplitude (or not at all).So I think it works as it should -- and each note plays at its own velocity.And that is maybe different to what DJKeys says that "it affects all notes played"?

title: RE: Poly Mod Morph question
post_content: OK, Baekgaard, you are  indeed correct.  I retested this with a single layer, default patch.  I set the morph so more velocity makes the sound softer as before, and was pleased to discover that each note will behave according to its Midi velocity (1-127). I was just hitting a chord before.  So it appears that the Velocity morph feature is indeed applied on a voice/note basis within a single layer! It works the same way for filter cutoff.  So true velocity switching can be done with multiple layers--dj

title: RE: Poly Mod Morph question
post_content: This is interesting and potentially better than I’d expected. Many thanks for your inputs.

title: RE: Poly Mod Morph question
post_content: I don't own a wave 2, I got the original wave, but I think I understand what Hector says. In the wave1 if you use only one layer (slot) and your sound consists of two oscillators, then a filter modulation through any morphing will affect both oscillators of that specific layer. Of course you can morph only one oscillator's shape or the balance between the 2 oscillators, but the filter is global for each layer. The question was exactly about this, if you can affect the filter for only one oscillator out of the two in each layer using the velocity morphing. In the wave 1 you can not, but if this is possible in the wave 2 then it must be written somewhere in the manual. However there could be a workaround to achieve the poly mod modulation but you you have to sacrifice two different layers.You use only one oscillator in each layer with modulation applied on the desired layer only.

title: RE: Poly Mod Morph question
post_content: alex78 wrote:I don't own a wave 2, I got the original wave, but I think I understand what Hector says. In the wave1 if you use only one layer (slot) and your sound consists of two oscillators, then a filter modulation through any morphing will affect both oscillators of that specific layer. Of course you can morph only one oscillator's shape or the balance between the 2 oscillators, but the filter is global for each layer. The question was exactly about this, if you can affect the filter for only one oscillator out of the two in each layer using the velocity morphing. In the wave 1 you can not, but if this is possible in the wave 2 then it must be written somewhere in the manual. However there could be a workaround to achieve the poly mod modulation but you you have to sacrifice two different layers.You use only one oscillator in each layer with modulation applied on the desired layer only.The NW2 has one oscillator per layer only. FM is handled sort of "within" that oscillator, and morphing of how much FM modulation you want is done via the shape control of the oscillator.The two architectures are thus somewhat different, it seems, and the"limitation" of the original wave is not applicable here.But I think I answered Hector's question above with respect to the NW2. The poly refers to whether individuals notes in a layer can have different morph values depending on that note's velocity or if all notes in the layer are morphed the same. And for velocity, morphing is polyphonic even within that layer.Sent from my phone in brevity

title: Did Nord Wave 2  fix AMP VEL/Velocity issue from NL4/NLA1?
post_content: I'm considering a Nord Wave 2 but is wondering if they fixed the velocity issue from earlier models.If you don't know what i'm talking about take a look at this thread:nord-lead-rack-forum-f12/nord-lead-4r-m ... 14127.htmlThe following features are pretty bad on the NL4/A1:ENV VEL for AMPENV VEL for MODAMP VELThe velocity scale is kind of exponential, meaning to get anything you have to bang the notes with a hammer.Playing soft to medium get you nothing or its even just plain broken.Example from my NLA1 if i morph velocity to pitch ctrl 0.0 to 10.0 i properly never go above 3.0 or 4.0 before im afraid of slamming the keys any hard in fear of breaking something.Is the general velocity morph more linearly scaled on the Wave 2 for things like filter cutoff, osc ctrl and output level?Also how do the 3 AMP VEL settings compare next to the Release Knob in the AMP ENV section on the Wave 2 do they have any noticeable effect allowing one to play a bit more dynamically using the sample library or are they useless like ENV VEL and AMP VEL on the NL4/A1?Thanks for your input!

title: RE: Did Nord Wave 2  fix AMP VEL/Velocity issue from NL4/NLA1?
post_content: I have no experience with the Wave 2, but I have the NL2X which has the same (horrible) keybed as the NL4 and NLA1, and I agree that it's quite hard to use velocity for accurate control of anything. In fact, I almost never use it, and when i do I program it more as an on/off control.I believe it's not so much a issue in the synth engine, but it has more to do with the low-quality FATAR TP7 keybed that Nord inexplicably used in most of its synths.The FATAR TP8 keybed in the Wave2 is MUCH better, I used it in lots of keyboards and it's much easier to control velocity with it.So my largely uninformed guess is that even if everything in the sound engine stayed the same (which is probably not true), the Wave2 will have better control of velocity,  just because of the keybed.

title: RE: Did Nord Wave 2  fix AMP VEL/Velocity issue from NL4/NLA1?
post_content: I morphed the filter control to the velocity (50 - 100%) on the Wave 2. To get the filter opened up to 100%, you still need to use some power. For me it's the same as on my NS2EX.I never really enjoy the velocity morphing, but it works. To say that it's much better..., I think that's personal.The 3 AMP VEL settings I find the same, I don't go the setting 2 or 3. With setting 2 or 3 you still have to use quite some hammering force. I just don't like to play that way.It is better than on the NLA1. To find out if you like it, it's best to try it in the store.

title: RE: Did Nord Wave 2  fix AMP VEL/Velocity issue from NL4/NLA1?
post_content: I'm guessing the Wave 2 does not have some sort of global velocity curve setting? This would seemingly solve the issue.

title: RE: Did Nord Wave 2  fix AMP VEL/Velocity issue from NL4/NLA1?
post_content: tsss27 wrote:I'm guessing the Wave 2 does not have some sort of global velocity curve setting? This would seemingly solve the issue.Looking through the manual and reading the responses to my questions elsewhere the answer is no!Major opportunity missed by Nord here. In my view since the NW2 provides menus for adjusting the master vibrato speed and depth, it could easily provide the same for after touch and velocity sensitivity and offset. I mean the NW2 even provides calibration for foot pedals! - most competitors don’t include this but do provide user velocity curves And after touch calibration. Come on Nord! LolBasically just having on/off for velocity control of the filter is extremely poor and similarly the limitations of the settings for VCA (equivalent) are really not where you’d expect a top quality synth to be in 2020! Even with morph the effect is limited by the overall sensitivity of the source.The NW2 engine is clearly capable of some very subtle, beautiful, musical creativity, it deserves a musician's interface that truly allows their skills to be articulated. title: NW2, 1.12, Headphone problem
post_content: Not sure if this started with 1.12 or before but I've been playing with headphones attached and sometimes when the machine powers up and/or when headphones are plugged in and out, the balance is about 90/10 towards the right. Usually a power cycle or unplugging/plugging the headphones in again fixes it - but then simply turning the machine off and back on will make it happen again which makes me think it's a hardware/firmware issue and not a headphone problem per se. Has anyone else seen strange behaviour like this?The sound doesn't seem to matter. There are no pan settings being purposefully triggered. Etc.

title: RE: NW2, 1.12, Headphone problem
post_content: This is more likely to be an issue with your headphone plug/cables/adapter. When you switch it on/off, there is bound to be some mechanical movement, which could impact the balance when the connection is marginal.Are you using an adapter from jack to minijack? It so, try another one (but don't buy the cheapest ones). Or maybe your headphone cable is slightly faulty and needs to be replaced?

title: RE: NW2, 1.12, Headphone problem
post_content: Thanks for the response and I agree that that would make sense but I'm using high-end studio headphones, gold contacts, the whole nine yards. I've tried multiple adapters as well and the problem occurs intermittently. Note the phones and adapters work fine in other equipment. All equipment is also plugged in through the same power conditioner. So there are very few variables that aren't the same. The headphone jack is tight in the NW2 so movement is nil once it's in there but I'm still experimenting to see what is going on.Time will tell...

title: RE: NW2, 1.12, Headphone problem
post_content: If you've tried multiple adapters and the problem is intermittently, it may be that some of them have the problem and others not... those adapters are frequently the culprit, it seems, if you start looking at threads around here on the forumIt may also be a combination of the adapter and the receptor in the NW2, possibly some dust on one of the contacts or whatsnot? I think it's not likely to be a component failure nor a firmware/software issue in the NW2; for one, it would then NOT go away by plugging/unplugging the cable...Also, even if you have a "more-expensive-than-a-Tesla" set of very-high-end goldphones, they still rely on a mechanical connection that is prone to these kinds of issues. Are the adapters you use of the same high standard (and note that even if some look like gold plated, they may not really be)? Also, in my experience, even if the cables themselves may be teflon coated and kevlar re-inforced, they eventually give up and could start to impact the sound if bent sharply or some such.One issue I've had with a connecter was that it had not been properly cleaned at the factory. So even if all looked ok, and it would work when plugged in, it "scratched" when you rotated the cable in the receptor. This was caused by "fluss" or some other soldering related remains and disappeared after a proper cleaning.Anyway, hope it goes away over time

title: RE: NW2, 1.12, Headphone problem

title: RE: NW2, 1.12, Headphone problem

title: NW2 AT and Velocity
post_content: I’m loving the sound quality and diversity of the new NW2, I’ve read the manual cover to cover so that I can fully understand the modulation and morphing facilities provided. This is because an instrument of this quality deserves the subtlety And nuance that can be added by after touch and velocity.It is disappointing that Nord have only provided a velocity on off control for the filter and a crude three step control for amplitude control. This places a huge emphasis on the velocity calibration on the instrument being right in the sweet spot for both these important modulation features. Otherwise velocity control is of limited use.On most of the NW2 competitors both velocity scaling and after touch scaling (sensitivity adjust) are available from a system menu (e.g. Kronos, Kurzweil Forte and DSI Prophet X) Nord has chosen not to provide this. Why? Are their in-house calibrations so much better than their competitors ? Or do they think that velocity and after touch control is unimportant?Perhaps the latter is the truth. After all Nord have yet to provide their standard sample libraries with the facility to hold velocity switched sample layers. This is something that all their competitors have done for years. It was one of the reasons I dumped the NS2 back in 2014 and 6 years later they still haven’t caught up.Maybe they don’t think velocity is important enough and that the beautiful subtly of the harmonic change made possible with switched velocity sample layers is something their customers need. To me it seems Nord are forever backward looking in their aim to produce products that replicate the sounds of at least 35 years ago.If the NW2 can have vibrato depth and rate adjustment in a system menu then why can’t there be velocity depth and scale for filter and VCA? And why can’t there be after touch sensitivity? These are obvious system menus.Pity because the NW2 could have been a lot more than another wall of sound producing slab. It could have delivered beautiful subtle instruments that have never been heard before. But for that you need exact control and access to nuance.

title: RE: NW2 AT and Velocity
post_content: You know you can use the velocity morph function to make any of the amp env and filter parameters change with velocity (in the positive or negative direction as you need)?That should provide quite a lot of granularity, one would think...Sent from my phone in brevity

title: RE: NW2 AT and Velocity
post_content: At least, the velocity to morph are working very well on the A1.I have not tried the W2 yet, but it are high on my wish-list.

title: RE: NW2 AT and Velocity
post_content: I suspect that because you can control the exact amounts of velocity and pressure with morphing, they don't include menu options; you're essentially setting a response for each patch. I can think of scenarios where this is not ideal and precise global keyboard response would be better, but generally it makes sense. However as far as the 1 velocity sample limit I agree 100%, this is so outdated especially since the piano library doesn't have that limitation but we are not allowed to create those.

title: RE: NW2 AT and Velocity
post_content: Thanks for the feedback. I would love to think that using velocity as a morph modulation source would provide enough subtle control over its effect. I’m sure we all know that mod wheel morph is good but just how much control is possible using velocity?Maybe someone can feedback as to how effective it is.Here’s a scenario:Let’s suppose we want to produce a velocity layered bass guitar sound. We can creat two sample maps (one for each velocity layer) and load them into the NW2. We can assign these to two of the NW2’s parts (one to each). We can then use velocity morph to control the vca level on each. The lower velocity part being morphed negativity so that for soft playing it will be loud and for hard playing it will be quiet. The second, high velocity, sample map part would be morphed positively so that it only sounds when played harder.So this (although crude) could be a way of providing velocity  switched (x faded!) sample playback.My guess is this should work but it may not be that effective without the ability to adjust the keybed velocity curve and sensitivity. It has certainly been my experience that this is necessary on other keyboards. Take the DSI prophet 6, a great synth but we fought long and hard to get Dave’s guys to add some usable velocity curves to it!! LolWith Kurzweil we actually persuaded them to add a per note velocity calibration facility for the Forte, this really improved the Fatar TP40 performance a lot.My view is morphs are a great feature but you have to get the modulation sources in the right range to provide usable control. That’s why there’s calibration for the external swell pedal..... Different people play with different strengths and all keybeds have tolerances. This means user calibration for velocity and after touch is important.

title: RE: NW2 AT and Velocity
post_content: Yes, that was what I meant -- you can use the velocity morph to control a quite wide set of parameters including also the layer volumes.It works as expected; you can morph all the way from no sound to full whack at the other end of the scale, going from MIDI velocities 1 to 127 (or the other way round). Specifically for the layer volume, you can use that in combination with the amp vel settings off, 1, 2 and 3, so in essence you can combine the 4 different scalings provided with your own scaling -- for instance, you could velocity morph layer volume from 5 to 10 AND use amp vel setting 2 if you want it to be a little softer at lower amplitudes, or the other way round, e.g. morphing from 10 to 5 using amp vel 3, which gives you just a slight scaling a bit like amp vel 1 (but probably with a slightly different curve).In addition, you can in many cases also morph the filter settings to open up the higher frequency content at higher velocities, making the tone brighter and louder and/or you can morph not only the filter frequency but also the envelope amount, so you effectively also have full control of how velocity sensitive it should be.I thought from your first post that you had a NW2 yourself, but if not, you should definitely try playing with the velocity morphing. I think it can do more creatively than what may be apparent from a quick read of the manual. At least I find that combining the different parameters e.g. the way I listed above gives you at least some of what you're asking for.My personal guess is that, as Nord is about well-designed and musical controls and less about offering abilities to tweak settings like the curves, that it is not likely that a velocity curve editor is added to the game. But I could very well be wrong, of courseThe swell pedal calibration is needed to make the instrument work with multiple pedals; I have several of different types and if the wrong curve is picked, it's not working well. So it's not so much about personal preferences, but more objectively that the useable range of one pedal may be only 20% of the entire range if the wrong curve is used.Hope this helps?

title: RE: NW2 AT and Velocity
post_content: Thanks very much for that. From that for me it’s definitely worth trying it out now! CheersBTW regarding swell pedal calibration: Nord seems to be at odds with most other brands.From my direct experience the following products all work fine without swell pedal calibration, but they all provide user selectable velocity curves or velocity offsets:-DSI Prophet 6Kurweil ForteRoland RD2000Roland RD700SX/GX/NXRoland RD800Roland Juno DiKorg KronosGenerally provided you choose the right tip/ring/sleeve assignment they work.Can't say the same for people's playing styles which is why they all have selectable velocity values.Even my NE3 73 doesn't have a swell pedal calibration. And since 2011 and many different pedals it hasn't needed one! lol

title: RE: NW2 Sample Library
post_content: DJKeys wrote:So, if I have and existing sample and load it into the NSE first, I can put it anywhere I want, that is what I was after!If you have the project files (.nsmpproj), having created the sample yourself, for instance, you can do this, yes.But you cannot open a sample you've downloaded from e.g. Nord's pages and edit/change that, since you only have the resulting "output" file (.nsmp3) and not the project files.I think this is on purpose, to protect the samples from being copied or reused in other contexts.

title: RE: Are the wave 2 oscillators and the stage 3 different?
post_content: Hello-I would encourage to read the Wave 2 manual on the Nord Website. There is a complete description of them starting on page 20.  All of the virtual analog oscillators (except the very basic ones) are different than the NS3. title: RE: Are the wave 2 oscillators and the stage 3 different?
post_content: As @DJKeys points out, the NW2 widens the palette quite a lot. title: Wave 2 patch memory structure
post_content: Another question for early Wave 2 owners, while Nord doesn't have a manual PDF up on its site: does a Wave 2 'Program' load all four slots/layers?On the A1, there's a distinction between single slot 'Programs', and multi-slot 'Performances', but I notice on the Nord web page comparing A1 and Wave 2 we get the info as per screen grab below. I assume that means the Wave 2onlyhas multi-slot memories, and no equivalent of an A1 program?Thanks.

title: RE: Wave 2 patch memory structure
post_content: My guess is this is correct and makes sense. You can still build the programs from any number of "slots/layers" turned on or off, with individual volumes.  I see this as a simplification and enhancement of the A1 structure--dj

title: RE: Wave 2 patch memory structure
post_content: There is no distinction like that on the Wave 2.  There are simply "Programs" that load whatever number of layers that were stored to that Program.

title: RE: Wave 2 patch memory structure
post_content: OK cool. Can you also say if layer enabling/disabling is glitch-free too, like on the A1? For example, if a W2 program has only one enabled layer, you can hold a note/chord with it, disable the layer, enable another layer, and the note/chord will have carried on sounding (and will until the keys are released).

title: RE: Wave 2 patch memory structure
post_content: artofmoog wrote:OK cool. Can you also say if layer enabling/disabling is glitch-free too, like on the A1? For example, if a W2 program has only one enabled layer, you can hold a note/chord with it, disable the layer, enable another layer, and the note/chord will have carried on sounding (and will until the keys are released).Yes, it’s like the A1.

title: Wave 2 First Impressions
post_content: Updated after more experience.I have been working wih this machine for a few days now just programming sounds for my Top 40 and classic rock stuff.  The instrument is a joy to use, has a great keybed and a rich sound. It is also much larger and heavier than any previous Lead (or the Wave).  It it is nearly the same size and weight as my NS3C.  There is a lot of guts to this thing. In my opinion (as misssoundscape's), this is not a new version of the Wave, but a completely new instrument in its own class with premier DNA from the entire Clavia/Nord family.Getting around is pretty easy, as it has a similar structure to the A1.  Tha Analog waveforms are incredibly useful and you can easily dial in a starting point when programming.  The Shape waveforms are especially notable, as the Osc Control can give you a wide range of sounds on a single waveform.  The unison feature adds real fatness and polyphony is more that I will ever need.The ADSR Envelopes for both the Amp and Filter have the same interaction as a classic subtractive synth.  All oscillators can be detuned up or down and the mod envelope can be set to negative values! The Filter envelope can be inverted as well, which makes for some cool possibilities.Using the A1 as my guide, I was creating sounds quickly and found myself saying, "wow, that was easy". I love that the shift and copy/paste buttons are right next to each other. The filters sound great, and being able to adjust the filter envelope amount is a cool bonus. Pretty much every needed parameter can be morphed. Also, the independent Wheel assign section is a great addition. The chorus, phaser, and ensemble sound great, but I have not yet been able to get the sounds I want out of the reverbs (that will take some more experience).  I would rather have two more adjustable Hall reverbs than a Cathedral which I really wouldn't use.I worked with the arpeggiator briefly. It is more advanced than the A1, and gives you the ability to store your own rhythmic patterns (but not your own notes). The solo feature in the Layer section is awesome and saves a lot of time, as you can just push one button to solo any layer when editing.The filter and the amp can both be over driven, but the quality of the sound of the distortion is really dependent on the filter settings and oscillator selection, so I need to experiment with that more. It seems the Drive in the EQ section is weaker than the filter drive.  The EQ drive doesn't seem to increase as you turn the dial, it behaves parametrically in my experience which is much different than my NS3.  I hope Nord can make the EQ drive more powerful going forward.If you load a sample, it has its own pre-programmed filter, so you will need to enable the filter to mangle the sample. The EQ is defaulted to logical frequencies, and the parametric mode allows nice sound tailoring.I also found that if I want to trigger sounds from my NS3 on different sides of a split and the NW2 is split as well, the split points must be the same notes.  Makes sense, but it had me confused for a while (that is not hard to do LOL).The 0.84 manual is still a little behind the curve, as the utility section opens the Arp pattern instead of Layer swap in version 1.02.  I believe things will catch up as the synth is used more and these small discrepancies are resolved. I apologize if my thoughts are a little scattered, as I pieced them together as I worked with the instrument.All in all, this keyboard is very flexible and above all sounds fantastic.-dj

title: RE: Wave 2 First Impressions
post_content: Great first impression. I also used my A1 as a guide to program my song-settings. That's why I believe the NW2 is the successor from the A1, rather than the original Wave.Go to the website to get the new updated manual. Some things are better explained in the new manual, like the midi section. There are some crucial changes in the new manual.

title: Nord Wave Parameters Drifting
post_content: Hello everyone,I am having a problem with my Nord Wave. For some reason the parameters seem to be drifting on their own. For example, I might set the filter to low pass, and change the frequency to 20,000Hz, but the filter will not stay there, it will move down slowly on its own even though I'm not touching the knob at all. This is happening with lots of parameters, and generally happens to whichever parameter was the last one that was edited.Does anyone have any ideas on what might be wrong? I've restored it to factory settings, and reinstalled the OS, and it's still happening. Any help would be much appreciated!

title: RE: Nord Wave Parameters Drifting
post_content: Check if the parameters changing are assigned to the wheel morph function. If so then it is the wheel that has the problem. I have the same issue with mine but I haven't take it for repair due to to the corona virus. It is not serious, just a screw inside the wheel mechanism that is loose and as a result the wheel moves when I hit the keys and changes the settings.

title: Pattern memory size?
post_content: Couldn’t find the answer to this in the manual, maybe somebody knows:How many custom patterns can be saved on the W2?Are they saved on a per program basis, or is there a limited amount of pattern space?Thanks.

title: RE: Pattern memory size?
post_content: I think you mean the arpeggio patterns?As far as I can see, you can save a custom pattern per layer in each program. So there’s no real limitation.

title: RE: Pattern memory size?
post_content: 1620 in totalThey are saved pr. layer, so there are 4 custom patterns (that can be loaded with a preset and tweaked to your liking) pr program -- of which there are 400 regular ones you can store and 5 live... i.e. 4*(400+5) = 1620.

title: RE: Pattern memory size?
post_content: Ok, good to know.Thanks!

title: Nord Wave 2 for piano sound and feel?
post_content: Hi there, I own a Nord Lead A1 as my only keyboard. I like it and have had alot of fun with it.But I want something more piano like to improve my actual keyboard playing, but at the same time I would like to not give up the synth part.I've been looking at the Stage 3 but that just seems overkill. I've also considered the Electro 6D but will then miss out on the synth part.Now the Wave 2 have been released and I'm wondering how good the piano sounds are on it, coupled with the slightly larger 61 keys and semi weighted compared to the A1's 49 synth action keybed.I think at the moment getting the piano feel is more important to me, but if the Wave 2 with the sample library can do 85% of the piano sound of the Electro 6D I would be happy with that.I don't have room for 2 keyboards. The Electro is 2/3 the price of the Wave2 but money is not really an issue.Can any Wave 2 owner or anyone else knowledgeable let me know how well the wave 2 can do piano imitation or will i be disapointed?I underestand the Electro 6D has an actual piano engine while Wave 2 is just sample playback, I've listened to the Nord Sample Library 3.0 pianos and they sound great to me.Thank you for your input and help, it is much appreciated.

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 for piano sound and feel?
post_content: Hi, there-If realistic piano feel and sound are important, the Wave 2 is not an ideal choice.  It cannot load the Nord Piano Library samples like the Electro. It can load piano sounds from the Sample library, but, those are very limited compared to the Piano Library, fewer and not nearly as detailed.  The keybed is 61 note semi-weighted waterfall, so it not close to an actually piano action. If money is no issue, keep the A1 and buy the Stage 3 76 or 88, which are both Stage Pianos which are much closer to what you describe. You would have the A1 engine in the Stage, and the powerful 4-slot A1.-dj

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 for piano sound and feel?
post_content: The Wave 2 is not the choice for more piano like feel or sound.

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 for piano sound and feel?
post_content: If you are wanting piano-like feel then a synth is not the right choice overall, Wave or otherwise.

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 early owners - how's the MIDI out?
post_content: I've received mine today, nice synth, the interface is very intuitive indeed.Software version is 0.84, so I think there will be an update in the near future, but I did not encounter any problems so far.In answer to the questions:1. Is there any facility for one side of a keyboard split (or perhaps an individual layer) to transmit on its own separate MIDI channel? Or is there just one global transmit channel (as on the A1).As far as I've find out, it sends midi via 1 global midi send channel (channel can be changed), but the is no split for the different layers. For midi-in its different, the layers can be  controlled via 4 different midi channels, or one global channel (tested). See also attachment, which contain photographed parts about midi from the users manual.2. Can the layer volume levels be morphed?Yes, this is possible.3. Did you receive a printed owners manual?Yes, I did, but I haven't looked into it in detail yet (intuitive interface)4. Is there a link to the electronic version?As far as I know, not (yet).

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 early owners - how's the MIDI out?
post_content: Romanwave wrote:How are flexible FM and wavetable engines? Do you miss seamless transitions?It looks like there is something as "seamless transitions" on board (or maybe it's the same, I have no experience on the Nord Stage 3, so I can't compare).When playing with the synth I stumbled to the "width" function in the keyboard split function.With this function you can set a "crossover" width: 1= no crossover, 6= six notes crossover, 12= twelve semitones. The sound fades the further you get away from the splitting point.Again, see attachment, this time the section aboutlayer control.

title: RE: Nord Wave 2 early owners - how's the MIDI out?
post_content: Re seamless transitions (and at risk of going a bit off-topic), it was always possible on the A1 in a limited way between different layers of a Performance. You could have layer A enabled, hold a chord (say), hit layer B button (which deselected A), and A wouldn’t be adversely affected by anything new in B. And so on for C and D. So if you could deal with your transition sounds being limited to groups of four programs, and stored them in a performance, it’s a solution. I’ll bet the Wave 2 does this too, albeit with better polyphony. No way of having seamless transitions between Performances though, I believe.

title: RE: How to ship your Nord wave properly
post_content: Yes, it should be enough.Wave inside the soft case inside a good rubust cardboard box. Fill all the empty space with bubble wrap (best option) or polystyrene chips or paper.For good measure, usually I also wrap the entire box in tape, to seal it and make it waterproof.I've sent and received many used items this way, and never had a problem even with clear signs of VERY rough handling by the carrier.

title: RE: Sound Library 2.0 vs Archive
post_content: Almost all 1.0 sample have been converted to 2.0, with just a few exceptions ( for example the Power Synth subpage which is "apparently" missing but still therehttps://www.nordkeyboards.com/sound-lib ... wer-synths)

title: RE: Sound Library 2.0 vs Archive
post_content: Thank you for getting back so quickly maxpiano.  Is there a list anywhere of the few exceptions that haven't made it over to 2.0? Or do I have to go through each folder on the Archive and compare the contents to what is available on the Sound Library 2.0 (I really hope not....)Mat

title: RE: Sound Library 2.0 vs Archive
post_content: mat6066 wrote:Thank you for getting back so quickly maxpiano.  Is there a list anywhere of the few exceptions that haven't made it over to 2.0? Or do I have to go through each folder on the Archive and compare the contents to what is available on the Sound Library 2.0 (I really hope not....)MatUnfortunately there is no list, so... but ... why would you need that? My suggestion is rather: search what you need in the newest library and then, if you can't find it, try the Archive.

title: RE: Sound Library 2.0 vs Archive
post_content: My understanding is that in the early sample days close attention was not being paid to optimizing audio files, trimming useless audio at the beginnings/ends of some files to conserve space.  The 2.0 library sounds which are duplicated from the archive have presumably been optimized in this and similar manners.On a similar note, 3.0 samples are not "better" than 2.o samples audio-wise.  The 3.0 spec adds metadata which can then be used by Nord Sound Manager, and by the instrument, for the purpose of providing better organizational capability.  The actual audio content is the same as found in parallel 2.0 samples.Bless, Pablo

title: RE: Sound Library 2.0 vs Archive
post_content: Hello does the Sound Manager automatically update N2 files to the N3 format?thanks.

title: RE: Sound Library 2.0 vs Archive
post_content: emergingstates wrote:Hello does the Sound Manager automatically update N2 files to the N3 format?thanks.yes, at download time if the target synth supports v3 it does.

title: RE: Layering 2 or more samples on Nord wave 2
post_content: musicaldudeist wrote:I was wondering if a work around for those who wanted more than one LFO could be to put the same source in two or more layers and have different LFO settings for each layer to achieve the same effects.  Does that sound like it could work?Unfortunately what your suggesting doesn't accomplish what two LFO's does.With two LFO's the 2nd LFO interacts with the 1st LFO creating compound modulation effects.

title: RE: Layering 2 or more samples on Nord wave 2
post_content: cgrafx wrote:musicaldudeist wrote:I was wondering if a work around for those who wanted more than one LFO could be to put the same source in two or more layers and have different LFO settings for each layer to achieve the same effects.  Does that sound like it could work?Unfortunately what your suggesting doesn't accomplish what two LFO's does.With two LFO's the 2nd LFO interacts with the 1st LFO creating compound modulation effects.Correct, actually it could work the same only if modulating the OSC amplitude, but not if modulating the OSC pitch (frequency) which is the most common case (or other parameters)

title: Can I use modulation on samples?
post_content: Here's my issue...I have a bunch of different synth sounds on my record that I have to transfer to our live show. I would LOVE to not have to use a laptop on stage, which is why I'm looking into samplers that have modulation capabilities.My question is…If I were to sample each synth sound from my record onto the Wave, would I be able to use the modulation and synth effects on the instrument using a sample-based sound? Or would it essentially play like a sample keyboard, similar to how the Nord Electro sampler works, where you can't use any live modulation when using sample-based material?Thx,CR

title: RE: Can I use modulation on samples?
post_content: Short answer:Yes you will be able to modulate the samples.Longer answer:Nord Electro's that have sample capability use a simple sample engine. It isNOTa synth engine.The Nord Stage and Wave2 contain full synth engines that can use samples as the oscillator source. You can manipulate the samples just as you would oscillators.

title: Factory Sample Bank out of date?
post_content: I've noticed that the samples in the Factory Sample Bank are all versions 1.4 and 1.5 as opposed to V2.  Does this matter?  If it does, has anyone done the tedious job of replacing them with V2 iterations?

title: RE: Factory Sample Bank out of date?
post_content: Just heard back from Nord:"The 2.0 format mainly included more features for metadata in the files, so the v2 samples will not give you any sonic improvements I would say"Anyone else share this view?

title: RE: Factory Sample Bank out of date?
post_content: The Wave was built way before sample format 2.0 was introduced, so it's not surprising that the factory banks are in 1.x format.Most 1.x samples were converted to 2.0 and you can find both versions on the website. They are sonically identical. The advantage of 2.0 is that they are slightly smaller in size, so you can fit more in the instrument's memory.The latest Wave firmware is fully compatible with 2.0, unfortunately format 3.0 is not usable on older Nords (and likely never will be, but you never know).

title: RE: Factory Sample Bank out of date?
post_content: Thanks for the info Spider.

title: self created sample volume low
post_content: Hi,I am the guitar player in a metal coverband. Our singer has a Nord Wave. We've decided to play a Rammstein cover. I used a wav file and cut it into several pieces to create the samples. I then imported those samples into the Nord Wave via the nord sound manager and nord sample editor (I also updated the Nord firmware to the latest version)Now, the problem is when we select the preset on the Nord where my custom samples are stored, the volume of those samples is very low, compared to all the other 'factory' presets on the nord. How can I increase the volume of my samples? Can I increase it inside the preset on the Nord? Or should I increase the volume with the nord sample editor first before importing it again in the Nord (if yes how can I do this)Since we use different presets live, we can't just adjust the overall volume on the fly as now there is a big volume difference between my samples and all other presets on the Nord.

title: RE: self created sample volume low
post_content: The best way to do this is to optimize the gain of the samples before you bring them into the sample editor. I'm not sure if there is a way to do it in the editor directly.

title: RE: self created sample volume low
post_content: Ok I'll try this thanks.

title: RE: self created sample volume low
post_content: Try to sample again that  audio with a higher gain or, if you cannot do that, normalize the .wav files using an audio tool such as Audacity before importing them in the NSE.

title: RE: self created sample volume low
post_content: I just boosted mine 20db and then re-downloaded to keyboard... same output volume. Very low. Anyone else had this? Thanks, Remy

title: RE: self created sample volume low
post_content: When you import the .wav into the sound editor, there is a function to adjust the volume on the "sample loop/stop" tab.  This adjustment is in the lower right corner and is indicated by a blue arrow.  I tried to capture this in the attached work doc.  This helped on mine, hope it helps you...tony

title: RE: self created sample volume low
post_content: Nord Sample Editor does also include a normalize function.

title: RE: self created sample volume low
post_content: twofarmers wrote:.there is a function to adjust the volume on the "sample loop/stop" tab.  This adjustment is in the lower right corner and is indicated by a blue arrow.That setting only changes the waveform display in the looping window, it's like a vertical Zoom button.On the Instrument tab there is a Sample Gain parameter. The amount of gain you can add really depends on the content of your samples. You just have to try a setting, download the file into the Wave and then play a bunch of notes at one time to see if you get any distortion. Polysynths naturally need some headroom to play chords.

title: release chances parameters indipenently
post_content: Hello, i Write here to know if someone of you ever had a similar issue on the nord wave:While i am playing a performance (but even When i dont and the keyboard is on) the display shows that the release parameters are changing independently without me  interacting with the keyboard. I guess it is a physical issue of the machine. I really hope that someone of you can help. Thanks Sarà

title: RE: release chances parameters indipenently
post_content: Hi Sara,Are those different parameters that are changing or is it always the same parameter? If it is always the same, then it is likely that a poti or a knob needs to be cleaned or exchanged. Should be no big thing.GreetsEumel

title: RE: release chances parameters indipenently
post_content: Hi Sara,If it is always the same release parameter that changes without touching it, then it is likely that this poti needs to be cleaned or exchanged. Should be no big thing. You can probably provoke the failure be giving the keyboards gentle hits with the hand somewhere.GreetsEumel

title: RE: release chances parameters indipenently
post_content: Eumel wrote:Hi Sara,If it is always the same release parameter that changes without touching it, then it is likely that this poti needs to be cleaned or exchanged. Should be no big thing. You can probably provoke the failure be giving the keyboards gentle hits with the hand somewhere.GreetsEumelHello Eumel, i can read in the display the release parameter changing from 68ms to 80ms, just to make an example, and so on. it continues sometime for a couple of times.Always different parameters. It could be, provoking it with a little hit but this happens even when the keyboard is on but no one is touching it or playing it.Thanks you very Much for these infotmation, Sara

title: RE: release chances parameters indipenently
post_content: HI Sara, as Eumel says it is probably a faulty potentiometer (the Release one) that needs cleaning or replacing (if you cannot do this yourself you should contact the official service, via see eko Music Group website)As a temporary workaround, if you don't need to change it while playing then put it to 0 (full left) before turning the NW on and leave it there.

title: RE: release chances parameters indipenently
post_content: maxpiano wrote:HI Sara, as Eumel says it is probably a faulty potentiometer (the Release one) that needs cleaning or replacing (if you cannot do this yourself you should contact the official service, via see eko Music Group website)As a temporary workaround, if you don't need to change it while playing then put it to 0 (full left) before turning the NW on and leave it there.It works!thank you very much for this advice, it saves my life and my next gigSara

title: "Super Saw" with the Wave
post_content: Hey Folks,I was wondering if anyone has done a convincing "super saw" sound with the Wave? It seems the Wave doesn't have enough oscillators (and no unison), so can I fake it with samples?thanks!- Taylor

title: RE: "Super Saw" with the Wave
post_content: Hi Tay,Why let the Wave's dual oscillator design or absence of a unison feature corrupt your thinking?  You have fine tune on OSC2.  Also, in the f/x section you have chorus and can set delay to super fast rate to fatten things up, too.  You should be able to dial something up without samples pretty quickly which will sound good, especially if you load the identical program into both slots A and B, and then bump a few of the aforementioned settings just slightly to create your own custom unison mode.And then to top that off, there are hundreds of synth samples in the Nord Sample Library.  Chances are good that there's a saw or two in there which will speed you along that task.Bless,Pablo

title: RE: "Super Saw" with the Wave
post_content: Pablo, thanks for your help!I'm getting a sound that, while not quite the typical many-saws sound, is quite cool! I'll have a look around the sample librarycheers- Taylor

title: RE: "Super Saw" with the Wave
post_content: And if you do not find one, how about making one in Audacity? You can generate sawtooth and square waves all a slightly different frequencies and mix them up, then load the result in the Wave via the sample editor.

title: !! NORD WAVE *OS* UPDATE REQUEST 2017 (paid update? Poll) !!
post_content: I thought I would create a new Nord Wave OS update request (Comon.. Land on V3 please!) and parse post v2.14 requests in here from the original thread. I know this is unlikely since the Wave is discontinued and last update was 2015... But I think doing this would benefit Clavia. It benefits them to keep their synths alive - it's their Synths being used more in YouTube videos, instagram clips, in studios with their clients (potential Nord customers), on stage, in instagram clips, etc, etc. It would also make some users super happy and want to buy more Nord, especially users who only own a Wave like myself.Try to keep features requests realistic based off what has previously been achieved with updates, although admittedly, I'm going to adventure outside that realm a bit likely. These are my personal feature requests of which it seems some others have also requested. I will parse their requests into here as well. I've also created a poll - willing to pay for this update or no?-Feature compatibility with the latest editor/manager features - Samples and programs linked by name instead of location #. Sample missing prompt with search/locate.(This is actually my #1 request because Im doing sample intense projects and this is pretty annoying and is resolved in other synths)-Polyphony limit via 'System' (I have a problem sometimes re-triggering duplications of the same note, eg, if playing a C-Chord, and playing the c note repeatedly, will result in stacked C voices phasing with each other)-Programmable MIDI thru on the output-programmable AfterTouch (this would be done by holding shift + the first C on the keyboard, pressing through to engage aftertouch, and then turning a setting... doing the same but on the first 'D', and turning knob will remove the link)-More expression pedal destinations +PLUS+ Multiple destinations: 'Destination 1', 'Destination 2', 'Destination 3'. That way it can be separate from the morph.-Ability to use sustain pedal as a gate/trigger instead.-allowing the wooden pitch stick to control other things, give it multiple destinations - ie could control filter while pitch shifting, or set pitch amount to '0' so that it just becomes another control.-tap tempo LFO rates by holding shift, and hitting the delay tap tempo - this essentially is a global 1/4 note clock.----^holding shift AND holding tap tempo enters you into a selection mode, where touching any rate or envelope parameter will engage into a division sync mode to the global tap tempo clock. ie, 1/1, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8/, 1/16th, etc. So for example, you hold shift and tap tempo. it enters you into the parameter clock division selection mode, you go to LFO1 rate, nudge the knob, now it is engaged into division and on the parameter screen when you move the knob you will see it switch between 1/1, 1/4, etc, etc. If you leave LFO2 alone, it remains free-time/hz.-More vibrato options and programability in the system menu:---Depth level---Aftertouch pressure to depth amount ratio control---Adtertouch pressure to rate option and amount/ratio control---vibrato attack and release envelope with multiple destination options: 'rate', 'depth', 'rate+depth', 'sync to filter-env', 'sync to amp-env'.---Additional "vibrato modes", including to use it as an additional LFO (LFO3) source with multiple selectable destinations via 'System Menu':-----^VIBRATO MODES: 'Vibrato', 'TREMOLO', 'LFO3', 'Vib+Trem', 'Vib+LFO3', 'Trem+LFO3', 'Vib+Trem+LFO3'-------^Ability to invert phase of LFO3 from vib/trem.-------^Depth of trem/vib is LFO3 amount - could have a LFO3 amount to depth ratio (1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 5:1, 10:1), as well as '-', '+', and '-/+' amount options.-------^Could potentially have same option for LFO3 rate, a ratio doubler (2:1, 3:1, 5:1, 10:1)------- (((Maybe LFO3 by default is linked to vibrato, but maybe LFO3 is an internal system LFO on it's own, could have independent rate, link to LFO1 or LFO2)))---Sustain pedal turns on vibrato.---Ability to lock current vibrato type to current program, so that it can be turned on/off(bypassed) without cycling the different vibrato types.-Option in 'System' to have empty programs be selectable as default square wave oscillators, ie, completely zero'd but with square waves selected, volume at half, only 'A' on.. I've created a blank-backup of this empty preset for this purpose. It's much quicker workflow when designing multiple ideas.-Naming programs using the keys, when in process of naming a program, holding shift and pressing a key will select a letter. The very first 'A' key-note on the keyboard is almost the perfect distance to the last key-note on the keyboard which would be a 'z' just utilize last two black keys to make it happenso, starting from first A could correspond to the letter A, through to G (A-A, B-B, C-C, D-D, E-E, F-F, G-G | A-H, B-I...and so on)screenshot_20170307_020935.jpg (185.12 KiB) Viewed 8113 times-ability to add our own wavetables through the editor/manager?-ability to expand memory for samples, with some instructions for us DIY'ers. or maybe utilizing the USB slot somehow.I would personally pay $200 to get all this added ^ it's nearly creating an entire new synth.

title: RE: !! NORD WAVE *OS* UPDATE REQUEST 2017 (paid update? Poll) !!
post_content: roberth909 wrote:Having spent some more time with the Wave, I still really need a deeper level of vibrato, it's very frustrating.  I would like a few other things as well, in order of preference...Please add some SYSTEM settings, that will not break patch compatibility, when the OS gets updated again, since that window has been opened recently.1.  Please add Vibrato Depth to the SYSTEM settings.  I would like the Max depth to be at least double what the current default depth is, the Min could go down to none, so we can add subtle modulation if desired.2.  Please add a SYSTEM setting for Chorus Mix, so we can control how much of the Chorus effect to add to the original signal.  It's a little heavy handed right now, for my tastes.3.  Please expand the SYSTEM Vibrato Rate, I'm not sure why it's currently so limited, open this rate for more creative purposes, maybe 0.2 to 20 Hz?4.  Please add a SYSTEM setting for Reverb Time Multiplier, so we can control the size of the rooms more.  x0.2 to x2.0 should be good, where x1.0 is the default, where the algorithms are currently at.  I'd like to use a bigger selection of smaller rooms, where the reverb adds more space than classic reverb.5.  Please add a SYSTEM setting for Delay Feedback Multiplier, so we have more control over feedback.  x0.5 to 3.0 should be good, where we can get really long feedback if desired.On my crazy wish list, add more filter types and use SYSTEM settings to exchange them out as needed.  I'm trying to think of ways of using the SYSTEM settings so that patch compatibility is not impacted, because after all these years, it's pretty hard to change anything that impacts that.Thanks!alcools wrote:1. The filters of the NL42. Split3. Assign morph to the aftertouch4. Save vibrato rate in the patch (not in the system)5. The same vibrato than the NL46. Same Reverb than the NL47. A reverb and delay for each SLOT, or at least, possibility to affect RVB and DLY to only 1 SLOT8. A bit crusher (like NL4 !)9. Arpegiator !!!Simply add sample to the NL4 (and AT, and digital screen) !But it's a request for a NW2 or NL5, not an upgrade !alcools wrote:10. More sample memory11. More samples in the NW (100 is not enought)Larsdka wrote:Hi, would it be possible in a Os to make it possible to do a split (just one,Please).This is the best synth that have been made for many many years,but it´s too Outdated (at least for me).

title: RE: !! NORD WAVE *OS* UPDATE REQUEST 2017 (paid update? Poll) !!
post_content: Just some other ideas here - both important for live "performance patching" or in this case live program creation/manipulation.-Zero Recall, this would be in 'System' - all the knob lights go on for knobs that aren't in their zero or nulled position, helping you quickly get the Wave back to 0. This is important if you are into doing performance patches on the fly, and you want to start from "zero" each time.-Skip selection for Osc1/2. Another important feature request for "performance patching", being able to select any individual Osc source without having to cycle them all. ie, jumping from Triangle, to FM. This could be achieved by holding down the Osc selection button, causing it to blink, and then you ghost-cycle through to your selection (which doesn't actually cycle through them in the sense of changing Osc sounds/source), once you land on the Osc source you want, you then press and hold again, and it goes straight to that source.

title: RE: !! NORD WAVE *OS* UPDATE REQUEST 2017 (paid update? Poll) !!
post_content: Pan via 'System'. Pan per slot, per oscillator. Would also be very useful for running dual mono. Ie, Bass on Slot A panned hard Left, and chords/lead on Slot B panned hard right.

title: RE: !! NORD WAVE *OS* UPDATE REQUEST 2017 (paid update? Poll) !!
post_content: I'd almost call this a bug, if you have a sound that morphs Output Level, because the morphing seems to be linear and audio sounds more natural when you crossfade logarithmicly, there is a dip in the audio level in the middle when you use audio morphing.  It's kind of unusable, for me, at least.  So any morphing that impacts audio "signals" should be audio/log taper, not linear.  I'm wondering if Morph across the whole Nord line just functions this way?  I've tried to find some examples online and I think it does?  Not quite sure?

title: Program slots no longer in correct order
post_content: Hey guys,I own a Nord Wave and like it a lot.Pretty soon after getting it 2nd hand, I did what plenty others here seem to do:Started chucking our programs and samples that don't fit me, and made my own.Wonderful.But now what's happened, is that all the programs appear out of order.I,e, when I click the program up/dn buttons, or scroll the wheel, it no longer progresses to the next or previous program.It will bounce from 1:01 to 3:69 to 2:24 to 1:22 as I click the up button, for instance.Does anyone have a clue how this may have happened, and how I may change it?My way to navigate programs now, is by clicking in Nord Sound Manager to choose which one I want.In the list in Nord Sound Manager, they're all listed in the correct order, have the right numbers and so on.But not so in the actual program memory of the synth.Thanks + cheers;Eivind

title: RE: Program slots no longer in correct order
post_content: Hi! Did you check the left-bottom indicator indicating sort-mode?Nord Wave has three kind of sort modes which list numerical, alphabetical, and categorical order.You can also change mode by pressing Shift+Chord botton.I hope it might you help.

title: RE: Program slots no longer in correct order
post_content: KnobTanaka wrote:Hi! Did you check the left-bottom indicator indicating sort-mode?Nord Wave has three kind of sort modes which list numerical, alphabetical, and categorical order.You can also change mode by pressing Shift+Chord botton.I hope it might you help.Aha...that's it!Thanks, KnobTanaka

title: RE: Program slots no longer in correct order
post_content: I guess this happens because there are empty program positions that the instrument "jumps" when moving from one program to the next available. You can very easily fix this in the "organize" tab in Nord sound manager, just by draging any program in the position you want. This is very helpful also if you want to rearange the programs for a gig.

title: RE: Program slots no longer in correct order
post_content: I now noticed it is not the same issue, but a matter of sorting as KnobTanaka said. Nord's engineers were smart enough to make the instrument skip the empty locations when scrolling between the programs!

title: Which sample goes with which program?
post_content: Apologies if this has already been answered (I have gone through the forum and read several posts, but no clear solution).Is there a way of finding out which samples are used in the programs?  I have a collection of programs and samples that have been created by a friend and I want to do some pruning.  Sound Manager 7.32 for Wave is very limited in its functionality - it doesn't show information about the programs or samples that lets you know their relationship to each other and the Relink button isn't available.I've seen some references in the Forum to two third party applications to solve this problem but I couldn't find one of them and the other loaded but didn't work.Any help gratefully received.Mat

title: RE: Which sample goes with which program?
post_content: I have done this on my Wave -- for ALL 8 banks of 128 programs each.  It can only be done manually.  The INFO feature found in Nord Sound Manager was added after the development of the Wave and was not made backwards compatible to the Wave, so plodding through programs manually one by one is the only way to do this.Bless, Pablo

title: Trouble Uploading A Backup - RESOLVED
post_content: I am trying to Restore a Backup file created by another Nord Wave user (so that I may use some programs he has created) but it is failing.  Here are the steps taken:1. User A (my friend) creates a backup .nwb file using the Backup function of the Sound Manager (v7) and emails it to me (156mb)2. User B (me) opens Sound Manager (v7) and uses the Restore function to select, open and restore the .nwb file sent over3. Sound Manager synchronises with my Nord Wave and asks me to confirm back up ('The contents of your instrument etc) and I click on 'Restore' button4. Sound Manager immediately says, Restore Failed Operation Not Allowed.I have checked this function using the Nord Factory backup from the website and I am able to upload this perfectly so neither the USB cable, the program or the Wave appears to be at fault.Anyone got any suggestions as to what might be going wrong?

title: RE: Trouble Uploading A Backup - RESOLVED
post_content: Do you have the latest OS on the Nord Wave (and your friend too)?

title: RE: Trouble Uploading A Backup - RESOLVED
post_content: Yes, they're both on 2.14.

title: RE: Trouble Uploading A Backup - RESOLVED
post_content: This is now RESOLVED.  The problem was that the backup I was trying to restore contained both old (.nwi) and new (.nsmp) samples.  Customer Support at Clavia very kindly (and quickly) separated the programs from the samples so I could upload them separately.

title: Neo ventilator
post_content: Hi. Is here somebody who uses a neo ventilator simulator with the nord or nord 5 D. Is thing thing a real differdnce ? Or is it trow away money?

title: RE: Neo ventilator
post_content: I have a Neo I and it is a great difference!I own an NE5d/73 and two real-hammonds, but with the Vent my  Nord5d/73 sounds like a hammond. the Neo makes the sound a little bit softer, because Nord-Hammond sounds very rough!the other question is, if you need such a perfect hammond-sound. I play in a cover-band and most of the time, I use the internal leslie-sims in hammond and in Nord (that means: no Neo), because no one hears  the "real-good-hammond-sound" in the mixture of sounds in the band no one hears. if you play alone, the Vent (I or II) could be a possibility for you!

title: RE: Neo ventilator
post_content: I have a Neo Vent.  Yes, there is a big difference.  But it stays home most of the time, since no one but me can seem to tell the difference, and less stuff is always better.  The built-in simulator seems to be enough Leslie to deliver the needed effect.

title: RE: Suddenly out of tune
post_content: Ciao Sara, I am afraid it may be a problem with the Pitch Bend lever; try to disable the Pitch Bend from your Program and see if it gets back in tune. If that is the case you will need to send your Wave for repair/replacement of the PB.

title: RE: Suddenly out of tune
post_content: Hi Sara, Max is correct.  It is not likely (really impossible, I think) for the System Menu Transpose function to suddenly shift by itself while playing.  It is much more likely that this problem is coming from the pitch stick.  Assuming that this is what's happening, it will be necessary to replace the pitch stick.  For a temporary solution, you can disable the PB function as to each program.  That's a lot of work for more than 1000 programs.  If you are in an "emergency" situation and want to avoid editing all your programs, it is possible to disable the pitch stick entirely by opening the instrument and cutting the four wires coming from the pitch stick.
