title: FM Synthesis - n00b question
post_content: Hello all!I'm a n00b with FM Synthesis. Trying to learn the principles involved with this, saw this vid which was a nice intro to the game:http://www.sonicstate.com/articles/article.cfm?id=148I'm curious on one thing that comes up in the vid around 3:45 as relates to the Wave... On the Wave, it looks as though when I adjust the "Shape" knob, that's effectively increasing the volume of the modulator. However, is there also a way to change the pitch so it changes which overtones are boosted?Just to clarify, I know that by using Osc Mod > FM, I can achieve this by adjusting the pitch of oscillator 2. However, just using the FM algorithms selectable on the LED, are there any ways to adjust the pitch of the modulator in, say, one of the 2-operator algorithms to that I can produce inharmonic frequencies in the overtones?Also, can anyone recommend a good resource--book, site, video, etc--sharing some FM tricks (EG how to create FM strings, FM brass, etc).Thanks!

title: RE: FM Synthesis - n00b question
post_content: I think the video you linked is one of the better sources. For me FM is a bit like voodoo. I just toyed around on my Stage 2 but the sounds I got sounded a bit like a combination of a whale song and a small dog being sat on by its fat owner. Horrible enough for my cat to decide to leave the room rather than having to endure it.I think the shape knob changes how much the modulator influences the carrier (and how much feedback there is)for that particular oscillator; unless you use Osc Mod, the shape knob for OSC2 will never have any influence on OSC1 and the shape knob for OSC1 will never have any influence on OSC2. This is what I get from the diagram on the bottom-left of page 22.Directly above this diagram it says:TheShapeparameter is used for setting the amount of modulation and/or feedback from none to maximum.I think this is the same as what you describe (increasing the volume of the modulator).If you use FM on an oscillator, you will actually have a carrier, a carrier + modulator or a carrier + 2 modulatorsrunning on a single oscillator. So you could actually have two FM sounds in a single slot (one on each oscillator) or four by using both slots. If you set OSC1 to a sine wave (either using 1-OP FM or by using the shapable sine options from MISC) and use Osc Mod, I think you're actually running 2 operator FM (OSC2 does not need to be a FM sound itself, but it could be). However, from this diagram it appears you influence just the carrier, not the modulator. So if you set OSC1 to 2-OP FM, you'd probably have two modulators modifying the same carrier instead of OSC2 modifying the modulator of the carrier on OSC1.The diagram in the section on Osc Mod (page 24) just shows OSC2 modulating OSC1; it doesn't show or suggest what it modulates (the carrier or the modulator(s)).Btw. have you looked at the Mod envelope? Could that be of any use?

title: RE: FM Synthesis - n00b question
post_content: Haha. Hilarious. I guess it's true that the Dutch speak English better than Americans!I've become decent at producing tortured FM whalesongs as well.The best I can figure out so far is that, going through the FM algorithms, you tend to create higher overtones when increasing the ratio of carrier to modulator. But I'm still on the hunt for any tips on how and why to apply any of the particular ratios, when to use feedback, etc.You're right that the shape knob only effects the particular oscillator, unless you're using Osc Mod, in which case the shape, semi tone control, and fine tune control of osc 2 all effect the tone of osc 1.Per your question, I believe that, when you're using Osc Mod, Osc 2 influences the "carrier" of Osc 1, since the "carrier" refers to what you actually hear, and you can set up Osc Mod regardless of whether you have an FM algorithm selected as your wave type for Osc 1 (and using FM terminology, all of the wave types have "carriers", but only the FM algorithms would also have "modulators"). I believe there is no way to effect the modulator volume or frequency of the modulators within the FM algorithms... although since I'm not very familiar with FM synthesis, I don't know if this is a relevant limitation.I did try out the modulation envelope to help control FM, and it does help add expression. BUT, one limitation of the Wave is that the envelope can only be routed directly to Shape 2 (and not Shape 1). You CAN use LFO 2 in Single Cycle mode to do something similar, but you have less control over Attack/Decay than with the envelope where you can set those values independently of each other.Something nice I discovered (and many probably already have) is that, when using Osc Mod > FM, and then detuning the Fine Tune of Osc 2, it creates a pulse (probably a natural phase effect), almost like an LFO is modulating the sound.

title: RE: FM Synthesis - n00b question
post_content: As I understand it (from the video you linked) a modulator can affect either another modulator or the carrier on a dedicated FM synth like the DX7. The Nord synths (and probably most other virtual analogs that do FM) are more restricted and a modulator can only modulate the carrier (and via feedback itself, which can be turned on/off).My DSI Poly Evolver also does FM on the digital oscillators and while it has even less features than the Wave when it comes to FM, you can create some pretty cool sounds when using feedback. I toyed around with that a bit yesterday, as it can do more FM tricks than my the Stage 2.Edit: it seems there is a trial (demo) version of Native Instruments' FM8 synthesizer. It has a really easy to use interface and is a really powerful FM synth. Might be interesting to look at.http://www.native-instruments.com/en/su ... -versions/

title: RE: FM Synthesis - n00b question
post_content: Thanks for the link! I've heard about that soft synth, wanted to check it out. Have to put it on the back burner, so I can focus on recording (the eternal struggle with gear vs work!!). But I think something like this is the only way to understand FM. Till then, my working knowledge is: (for the most part) that the higher the ratio of modulator to carrier, the higher frequency the overtone is, and the more "amount" you add, the more you boost that overtone. This isn't always the case, and I still have almost no idea what's going on in the 3-Op algorithms--whether it's a linear link from modulator 1 to modulator 2 to the carrier, or if there are direct links from both modulators to the carrier...so more investigation needed.Also, I've been reading this *excellent* series to help understand synthesis in general, and here's an installment about FM:http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/apr00/a ... ecrets.htmIt's all very theoretical and often gets down to trigonometry to explain the math behind the sounds, but it's really great, and there are 40-50 articles like this.BTW, love the Poly Evolver. I spent a few weeks deciding between that and the Wave, but ultimately picked the Wave because of the samples and polyphony. I don't regret that decision at all, but I do love that blue synth! Now, if they only come out with a desktop version of that...

post_content: OscBombs wrote:Now, if they only come out with a desktop version of that...Or did you mean with the 4-voice polyfony?

title: RE: FM Synthesis - n00b question
post_content: Yeah, I meant the poly. But nice thought!

title: Program Change issue Stage-Wave
post_content: Hi there,I've bought a new Nord Wave last week and I'm using one of it's banks to create sounds which I use with both my Stage EX and Wave. For instance, Stage's 1:1's grand piano program is accompanied by Wave's 8:1's windwoods.However, after I adjusted some settings in the MIDI and External Sections, I can't seem to use the program change function. MIDI cables are correct for I can use both of the keyboards as a slave for the other one. In both menus, Prgm Change is set to Send&Receive. Even when I turn the Program Dial Knob, the MIDI transfer action light turns red for a moment, but nothing happens. It did a few days ago. I just can't seem to find the problem.What am I doing wrong?Pim

title: RE: Program Change issue Stage-Wave
post_content: Do you have a MIDI interface for you PC or Mac? The easiest way to troubleshoot this (I think) would probably to connect your Wave's MIDI out to that interface and use a small piece of software (MidiOx on Windows, MIDI Monitor on Mac) to show incoming MIDI data. Now change the program on the Wave and you should see in MidiOx/MIDI Monitor on which channel the Wave expects the program change (because it sends it out on the same channel, if you've set it to Send&Receive).Now do the same with the Stage (have it send a program change via the remote section) and see if the channel used matches the data the Wave is expecting. Provided you have the utility (MidiOx/MIDI Monitor) installed and a MIDI interface to hand, testing this will probably take less than a minute.Btw. are you sure that Wave actually works correctly?

title: RE: Program Change issue Stage-Wave
post_content: Thanks! It somehow managed to work, so I won't be changing the settings anymore, haha. Thanks a lot.

If yes, how a NordLead/2x or a NordStage/2 filter envelope works?

post_content: ...is anyone interested in this post?

title: RE: Has the NordWave a filter-envelope bug?
post_content: Well, I was typing a long reply a while ago, but didn't really have the time to do it properly so I thought I'd just let someone else do eet. But apparently noone did :-p

title: RE: Has the NordWave a filter-envelope bug?
post_content: saverio wrote:Playing "staccato" notes, the filter envelope retriggers the entire attack time from zero (relative zero obviously) at every keypress; and this is ok but, if I set along release timeand i play staccato but quick notesI should hear the filter quite open at every keypress, not at zero (or relative zero) value sounding closed...Unlike analog synths, digital synths start oscillators, LFOs and envelopes from the absolute start. Free-running oscillators, LFOs (unless it's a global one) and envelopes are generally unavailable since they're more difficult to implement on a DSP (digital synth), while on an analog synth it is hard not to implement a free-running one.From your description above I get the impression you expect the filter to be open when you play the second staccato note (because of the long release). However, it will not be open; the envelope will restart from the beginning and will start opening again. This is assuming you've set up the program you are playing to be monophonic (possibly legato).Even though the Wave has two slots (it is bi-tembral), it has 18 voices which are dynamically allocated where needed. Every voice is separated from the other ones and has their own oscillator, LFOs and envelopes - it is essentially just a bit of computing power on the DSPs in the Wave. If you retrigger a sound (that is set to be mono instead of polyphonic), it might not even start on the same 'voice' like it would on a real analog synth. Since that new sound has its own oscillator (because its on a new 'voice' and/or the oscillator is restarted) the phase of the sound may change. Even if the attack of the amplifier envelope is set to 0 and the filter is all the way open there might be a little dip in volume - I haven't looked at if this is the case on the Wave.saverio wrote:This soundsvery strangeto me because I played other synthesizers (like Korg MS20, Moog Minimoog and also digital ones like Minimax ASB etc...) and this is the first time I hear this kind of behaviour in a filter envelope...Well, the 'analog' synths I've played with had digital oscillators (DCO's), LFOs and envelopes and and analog (low-pass) filter (and amplifier). Stuff like the DSI Prophet '08 and Poly Evolver and small custom synths like the Immutable Instruments Shruthi-1. On my virtual analogs (like a Waldorf Blofeld and Access Virus TI) it worked similarly.

title: RE: Has the NordWave a filter-envelope bug?
post_content: A firmware update would be more than welcome for many reason (already listed), but .... I think that clavia will not invest time anymore in the NWwhat a pity

title: RE: Has the NordWave a filter-envelope bug?
post_content: saverio wrote:so, this maybe a precise choice by Clavia, because other virtual analog synths sounds different.Ehm, I don't understand it; maybe I wasn't clear in my earlier post.I think the envelopes on the Wave work exactly the same as on pretty much every othervirtual analog, such as the Waldorf Blofeld, Access Virus TI and Nord Lead 2X (I've had those, but don't have them anymore). Envelopes get retriggered (start from the beginning, the attack part, again) when a voice starts a new sound (which might actually be the same note). This is especially noticible if you set the Wave in mono mode. The same goes for LFOs.If, however, you set the Wave in legato mode, envelopes do not get retriggered. The downside is that the voice does not immediately sound at the note corresponding to the key pressed, but instead slides (glides) to the new value. The speed with which this happens can be set with the Glide knob. Note that on the Wave you can only use legato in monophonic mode (it is a specific mono mode). See page 16 of the manual for more info, the 'Mono Mode button' section. On something like the Moog Little Phatty this works the same way.Unlike the other Nord synths (except maybe the Nord Modulars), the Nord Lead 3 (three) can actually be set to a polyphonic legato mode, in which envelopes don't get retriggered. I haven't looked at the details though. On my DSI Poly Evolver you can turn retriggering of envelopes off; if you don't they work the same as on the Wave.I'm sure I can babble about some more somewhat related things and start on DCOs and VCOs, but that probably won't make things clearer.

title: How to create a program using sampels
post_content: Hi Guys,Can you suggest me which is the best way to create a program using the sample?Start from an existent program? initialize  a program using the SAMPLE INIT function?Any particular trick?Thanks a lot

title: RE: How to create a program using sampels
post_content: You'll become more familiar with the keyboard if you start from the sound init.

title: RE: How to create a program using sampels
post_content: It probably depends on the type of sound you want to make. If there's already some sound on the Wave that is somewhat similar to what you want to achieve, you might want to copy that program to a new location and have it use your own sample. You can then tweak the program which might already have usable envelopes, etc.But to be honest, starting from scratch might be a better idea. It is very enlightening to take an existing program and to play around with the settings. How is it constructed, what determines the sound, etc. I would suggest turning off any active morphing, because that simplifies matters. Playing around with the rate (speed) and amount of LFOs, the filter cut-off and decay/release on the amplitude/filter envelopes is probably a good place to start.I you have some sound you like in slot A, you could copy it to slot B and tweak it there. It is then really easy to compare the sounds or to play them at the same time. An A-B comparison if you will

title: RE: How to create a program using sampels
post_content: Thanks a lot for your answer, I'll try to play around following both the solution becouse both presents some interesting aspects

title: newbie slots A and B - how to store
post_content: greetings! i'm having difficulty storing sounds into slots ?i copied program 1.1 to bank 6.1 to setupa layer combination strings + piano.i wanted to have slot A be the Full Strings soundand have slot B be the Grand piano sound.how do I change the slot B sound?what sequence of keys needed to assign sound into slot?no matter what keys sequence i try from manual description,slot B is always a synth sound.any help or step-by-step appreciated, thanks!

title: RE: newbie slots A and B - how to store
post_content: Hello freddie_tane,Have you turned the Memory Protect feature off?Seems simple enough, but many miss this step.Starting with bank 6 program 1 selected.Set the NS2 so that Slot B has focus (using the Focus button between the encoders)Now press and hold the Slot B button and turn the Value Dial until you find the sound to be copied "Grand Piano sound from 6:1 or 1:1" when you release the Slot B button, that sound is in the edit buffer.Change focus to Slot A and repeat the process by finding the Full Strings, make any additional edits, then store the program to any location you wish.Cheers, Hanon

post_content: Hello threlf,The Wave is a very capable synth.I'd have to give the nod to the Prophet 08 for this one.The advantage of the Wave would be that in addition to good synth capabilities, it can also use samples as a sound source to be processed through virtual synth architecture.Whereas the Prophet is just a great synth.I watched a couple videos of the Editors live.It looked as if they had a MIDI'd acoustic piano, Moog Minimoog Voyager, Korg Microsampler on stage.I agree with sakari that an Access Virus could be a good possibility.I've owned the Virus KB and it was great.The TI2 may be on the upper edge of your price range.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Nord Wave or DSI Prophet 08 - or something else?
post_content: If you're thinking about getting a Nord Piano 2 but are also interested in a Wave, maybe you should have a look at the Nord Stage 2? Yes, the Nord Piano 2 has a synth section and can play samples, but it is rather limited. The Nord Stage 2 gets you Nord's organs (which you may not be interested in) but also about 60-70% of the functionality of the Nord Wave (as far as the synth section goes). Note that the Nord Piano (both 1 and 2) does come with the tripple pedal as standard, while it is an optional extra for the Stage (increasing the price difference).

title: RE: Nord Wave or DSI Prophet 08 - or something else?
post_content: If you are looking into DSI products, would recommend considering a DSI Tempest. It has a powerful analog part together with digital oscillators (in a sense, it's an "evolved" evolver), a nice sequencer and many hands-on controls. And future upgrades are said to make a full-blown 6-voice, 4 oscillator-per-voice synth out of this little beast.I own both the Wave and the Prophet '08, they mix well together. One should mention however that the sound of the Prophet is rather harsh, not "Oberheim-smooth" (as compared to my OB Matrix 6).

title: RE: Nord Wave or DSI Prophet 08 - or something else?
post_content: i would rather compare the Prophet to a Nord Lead over the Nord Wave... if it's analog you want...

title: Sample downloads not the same as online demos?
post_content: I recently downloaded a couple samples from the Nord Sample Library--based on how great they sounded on the Nord sitehttp://www.nordkeyboards.com/main.asp?t ... trMachinesI noticed when playing with the Roland VP-330 samples RMI Electra Lute and VP-330-Male4Female4_01 that they sound very different from the recorded performance on the Nord site by Åke Danielson. Basically, the RMI Electra Lute sounds a lot flatter/EQ'd differently, etc, and VP-330-Male4Female4_01 is lacking the "stuttering" effect.Would anyone know if the sounds from the recorded performances were actually recorded on the Wave, and if the same sounds can be achieved?I'm guessing that the "stutter" effect is from assigning a Saw or Pulse LFO to either Pan or Resonance, but I can't get it to sound exact... And as for the RMI Electra Lute, I have no idea how to bring out the same texture and overtones (Resonance and Overdrive, maybe?).Any suggestions?

title: RE: Sample downloads not the same as online demos?
post_content: The sample downloads are just, well, samples. The sound you hear is based on programs, which includes filter and envelope settings, etc. They're building blocks for making your own sounds, not finished sounds in their own right. Remember you can use the samples on the Electro, Stage 2 and Wave while you wouldn't be able to share programs between those three.If you go to the product page on the Wave and then choose Program Library at the top, you go to a page with quite a few programs for the Wave. Most use samples, but not all, and the ones who do use the standard samples.I think a lot of not most of the examples are recorded on the Wave, since it has the most extensive means of modifying a sample-based sounds (though the Nord Stage 2 has more effects). So yes, I think you should be able to recreate those sounds (given the sound design skills and some patience).Probably not the answer you were hoping for though.

title: RE: Sample downloads not the same as online demos?
post_content: OscBombs wrote:I'm guessing that the "stutter" effect is from assigning a Saw or Pulse LFO to either Pan or Resonance, but I can't get it to sound exact... And as for the RMI Electra Lute, I have no idea how to bring out the same texture and overtones (Resonance and Overdrive, maybe?).I think they're using an LFO to modify the cutoff for the filter. I do think I heard some panning though.

title: RE: Sample downloads not the same as online demos?
post_content: Thanks. Well, it's at least good to know that the sounds in the recordings are, in fact, using those samples in the programs. I thought at first the wrong samples were being referenced on the Nord site. Alas, as you say, it will just take a little bit of patience. I'll give frequency a shot, and maybe with some of the different filters (might be cool to try to set the LFO to increase the Q on the band pass filter... we shall see...)

title: Octave shift when triggering a vst
post_content: Hello,I have a question concerning the octave shift function of the Nord Wave.When I am using the Nord wave to trigger a vst instrument, the Wave triggers C0-C5 of the vst instrument. When I try to use the octave shift function to trigger the higher octaves  of the vst instrument, it doesn't work.I also own a Nord Lead 3 which I also use to trigger vst instruments, and when I hit c3 and the octave shift of the Lead is in the middle, it triggers the c3 of the vst instrument. If I octave shift the Lead 3 by one octave, and play a C3 on the Lead, it triggers a higher octave in the vst.With the wave, whatever vst instrument that I load, it always triggers C0-C5.I tried changing the settings in the Wave but I didn't find a solution. Has anyone encountered the same problem or anyone has a solution?ThanksRoss

title: RE: Octave shift when triggering a vst
post_content: resonance wrote:Hello,I have a question concerning the octave shift function of the Nord Wave.When I am using the Nord wave to trigger a vst instrument, the Wave triggers C0-C5 of the vst instrument. When I try to use the octave shift function to trigger the higher octaves  of the vst instrument, it doesn't work.I also own a Nord Lead 3 which I also use to trigger vst instruments, and when I hit c3 and the octave shift of the Lead is in the middle, it triggers the c3 of the vst instrument. If I octave shift the Lead 3 by one octave, and play a C3 on the Lead, it triggers a higher octave in the vst.With the wave, whatever vst instrument that I load, it always triggers C0-C5.I tried changing the settings in the Wave but I didn't find a solution. Has anyone encountered the same problem or anyone has a solution?ThanksRossHello resonance,Welcome to the forums.Hi Ross,The Wave's Octave Shift functions as Nord intended and doesn't affect the outputted MIDI notes.Wave Maual, Page 16 wrote:Messages from the Nord Wave's MIDI Out will not be affectedHowever, you can accomplish your goal by using the Global Octave function by pressing theGlobalbutton (Shift+Octave Shift)Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Acoustic Piano / Electric Piano from Electro 2?
post_content: Welcome to the forum Freddie.I don't know the Electro 2 itself, but if it uses the normal Nord Sample Library (like the Electro 3, Stage 2 and Wave) then you can indeed load the same samples on both.With 'normal' I mean sounds created with the Nord Sample Editor or found at this location:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/main.asp?t ... le_LibraryCheers,Mathijs

title: RE: Acoustic Piano / Electric Piano from Electro 2?
post_content: The Wave does not have a Piano Sample partition, just a partition for other samples. You could load a custom sample you or someone else created,, but the Wave does not have the ability to load samples from the Nord piano library because the internal design is different from an Electro 3, which can.

title: RE: Acoustic Piano / Electric Piano from Electro 2?

title: RE: Acoustic Piano / Electric Piano from Electro 2?
post_content: I don't think there has been a lot of demand for piano samples on the Wave so far because the Wave is a synth first and foremost. An accurate multi-sample of an acoustic piano with good looping is not an easy task and would be pretty large. Electric piano samples tend to be much smaller. Definitely possible to do, but I don't know of any that are currently available.-dj

title: One shot samples
post_content: Hi,I tried today to move some drum samples into my Nord Wave via the Nord Sample Editor. Unfortunately it didn't sound right because I couldn't get the samples to play like a "one shot sample". Is it possible to do that with Nord Sample Editor and a Nord Wave?

title: RE: One shot samples
post_content: What is the symptom, does the sample repeat itself?When creating the sample instrument, did you set the loop setting to "No Loop"?

title: RE: One shot samples
post_content: Alternatively you could loop the silence at the end of a sample, but that's a bit of a hack.

title: RE: One shot samples
post_content: I want the samples to play all the way through even if I don't hold down the key. Now it's only playing the sample for as long as I hold down the key. For example in EXS 24  in Logic there is a alternative for "one shot" that makes the sample play all the way through when you hit the key. Is that possible in Nord Sample Editor?

title: RE: One shot samples
post_content: Have you tried setting a really long release?

title: RE: One shot samples
post_content: Yep, release does this.

title: RE: One shot samples
post_content: I would consider this a bit of a hack too, but if your sample is fairly short (and does not loop), you can fake playing a sample -without- an envelope with a really long release (45 sec is the maximum in the Wave)  and nobody is going to notice your volume is going down slowly. It would be nice if the Wave could play samples one-shot, but it's not a sampler but a synth that happens to be able to use samples.

title: RE: Wave discontinued
post_content: Discontinued or not, the Wave is still a very cool board. If it is discontinued, which would not surprise me, would it really make a difference? Clavia keeps updating the sample library, the OS is stable and while we might want to see some new features, Clavia is unlikely to implement those in the existing Wave regardless of whether it is a current product or not.I'm not holding out for a Wave 2, as in my opinion the Stage 2 coverts that area fairly well. Instead, I think it would be great to see a new synth (something to use alongside the Stage or Electro) based on the Nord Modular line of products. Something like a souped up Modular G2, with the ability to use samples and wavetables as an oscillator source (like the Wave); ideally it would also have some inputs so all that DSP power could be used with some great effects on both the inputs and internally generated sounds for even more possibilities. I think Clavia already has all the technology to create something like that. If they were to combine it with a more up-to-date interface to use in the studio (since I doubt you'd be tweaking it a lot in the field) and 37 or 49 keys, that'd be a sweet deal. I think a touchscreen might give them a lot of flexibility to tweak the interface on that thing and might even allow them to keep costs down, but I don't think a touchscreen would be ideal for live use, you'd at least want some decent knobs and buttons. A fairly large monochrome graphic display (320x240) with some soft buttons to the sides and bottom could make a nice alternative that would work better in the field.Anyway... I doubt Clavia would sell a significant number (just like the Wave, probably), certainly not like the numbers of Stage and Electro boards they sell. It wouldn't surprise me if Clavia left the synth spot in their product line open for a while. While it is a bit sad the Nord Lead 2X survived both the Nord Lead 3 and the Wave, it still sounds excellent. As a VA it is much more capable than a Stage 2, so it makes a nice match with the Stage 2 for certain types of sounds (of course, you could just use samples on the Stage 2).Hurray for speculation.

title: RE: Wave discontinued
post_content: It has been awhile since the wave and lead were updated, so why not..hopefully something with graintables as well...a new knobby synth...I have been looking at the virus, but a new clavia would certainly tempt me....

title: RE: Wave discontinued
post_content: I have a love-hate relation ship with the Virus. I bought a Virus TI Polar two years ago, but grew tired of it after a few months and swapped it for a Nord Wave. A few months after that, I missed my Virus and got a 2nd hand Virus TI keyboard, which got sold again to help finance my new Stage 2.The Total Integration (TI) stuff always worked fine for me (used to be really buggy) and you can create some very amazing sounds with it (especially really nice pads), but for some reason the sound doesn't really convince. Every time I hear my Poly Evolver I can hear why I still have it. The oscillators on the Virus sound a bit thin to me though; with layers of effects applied (which almost all presets have) they sound fine, but 'bare' oscillators fail to convince. For example, I think the oscillators on the Nord Lead 2X sound better. On the other hand, the build quality of the Access synths is excellent (as with most German engineering, except Behringer) and you can definately do very cool things with it.I'm sure I'll get another Virus at some point though. I'm missing my 2nd already.Maybe I'll get a module next time.The Virus is excellent for electronic type sounds, especially if you want to do sound design. It is a rather complex synth with lots of menus to navigate, but if you use the TI software from a DAW it suddenly becomes very simple to use.I wouldn't mind Clavia making a synth with a nice set of effects, lots of different oscillator types, etc. like the Virus.Edit: lots of typos

title: RE: Wave discontinued
post_content: interesting comments mj... The Poly evolver is on my alternatives list....I thought the virus had a minimum of menus...oh well..

title: RE: Wave discontinued
post_content: sakari wrote:interesting comments mj... The Poly evolver is on my alternatives list....I thought the virus had a minimum of menus...oh well..It has lots of knobs and buttons but because you can do so much with it, several knobs and buttons have more than one function. For example, if you push the Reverb button, a menu will open with the settings for the reverb. By turning the knobs below the display (or by using the buttons to the right of it) you can change the type and several associated parameters. Some menus will have more than one page and you will need to press buttons to go to the page you want.So while there are lots of 'menu screens', you can generally just open the one you want by pressing the associated button. The display will show you what you are doing and things such as the current value of whatever you're changing. A page has three values you can change with the knobs immediately below them. So in a menu with just one page you press a button and then turn a knob to change the setting.With the wave you have some thing similar for some parameters; for example, you press a button to set osc2 to a sampled wave and then turn the rotory dial next to the screen to select the one you want.There are also three user-assignable 'soft knobs' (the ones below the display); you can assign a function and name to them. It makes sense to assign a parameter to them that does something useful to the current sound but that does not have a dedicated knob. Something like a 'bit crusher' type effect is a good example.For standard stuff like changing filter cutoff you have dedicated knobs. However, for oscillators, LFOs and modulation sources you first press a button to select the right one (3 oscillators, 4 LFOs and 6 modulation sources) after which you can change rates and stuff. If you want to change more in-depth parameters (uni- v.s. bi-polar LFOs for example) you may need to press the 'edit' button in that section to open up the associated menu.So yes, there are lots of menus, but it is easy to get to the right one and during performance it is unlikely you will need to use them. For studio work the Total Integration software is more convenient as it groups related parameters on one screen, where they are easy to change with the mouse (mostly sliders and knobs) and where they often have some sort of visualization to show you what you are changing.As far as I know the only thing you cannot change on the Virus TI itself is user defined arp patterns. You can select arp patterns and associated parameters. Instead, you draw (width and height of bars) your custom arp patterns in the TI software and then store them so you can select them on the Virus.

title: RE: Nord Wave delay vs. Stage Classic delay
post_content: I think the chances of getting that delay in the Wave are very slim. It looks like the functionality of the Wave is set in stone, especially if it will be discontinued (as someone posted). I think the Wave was, in part, a platform to test out new technology (as was the Nord Lead 3). Technology of both ended up in the Stage of their time (NL3 -> Stage, Wave -> Stage 2). Now the synth section of the Stage 2 can do a lot of what the Wave can (certainly not everything though) the Wave might be a bit obsolete.Also, if you look at which sub-forums are the busiest here you'll find it is the Stage forum, followed by the Electro forum. I think that should, at least to a degree, reflect which products they sell the most. I wouldn't be surprised if Nord were to focus more on the Stage, Electro and organ lines of products. And there's that drum synth of course, but that's likely done by a different development team. If someone's just going for features, sampling and huge libraries I think a Korg Kronos, Yamaha Motif XF or even a PC with soft-synths might be a more obvious choice. That's all well and good for in the studio, but isn't live musicians typically a crowd that will buy Nord instruments? Of the alternatives I named, I think none as the immediacy and ease of use of a Nord.Anyway, pure speculation.

title: Complete Nord sample library in one download?
post_content: Does anyone know if it is possible to download the complete Nord sample library in one download? It is very annoying to download all the sample sets separately from Nord web site.If someone has went through this and Nord doesn't offer the option to download all sets in one download (which it doesn't as far as I know), could someone maybe upload the complete set into a file sharing site? Thanks in advance!

title: RE: Complete Nord sample library in one download?
post_content: Putting contents of the Nord Sample Library somewhere on the internet would not be legal.I'm sure there are plugins for browsers like Firefox to download, for example, all zip files a specific page links to. If you do use some kind of tool (or browser plugin),pleasepleasePLEASE restrict yourself to a single connection. If you use lots of connections, you may speed up your download a bit but you will cause excessive load on the Nord website and impact other users trying to access their website.I used a command line tool (wget) on UNIX to do this, but I'm sure there are Windows (and OS X) versions. You'd point wget to the individual pages in the sample library and tell it to spider 2 levels deep and only store (and fetch) zip files (wget -r -l2 -A zip<url>). A tool similar to wget is curl and it is installed on OS X by default. Unfortunately you can't tell it to only (download and) store specific types of files. Anyway, this is all probably not of much use to youCurrently there is about 3.2 GB of content in the sample library, so it would be quite a sizable download.

I didn't even find any mention of such restriction at the web site.Also, 3.2GB isn't really that big by todays standards. title: RE: which sounds have samples
post_content: Steff10er wrote:Hi!What happens to the presets which contained a deleted sample?They don't play correctly anymore. Some may be entirely silent (if the sample was their only oscillator), while others will sound like a large portion is missing.If a sample is missing, the sample number will be flashing in the display of the Wave, signaling a missing sample.Does a preset accesses an exchanged sample with the same old settings or will this preset be crushed?The Wave is not aware the sample has been changed, so it will happily play the new sample at that location. The program itself remains unchanged, so if you accidentally overwrite a sample and fix it again, well, you've fixed itThis makes managing samples a bit cumbersome, as there is currently no way to automatically rearrange samples (and modify the corresponding programs) when you add/delete samples. So if you want to add two sounds that use the same sample (by sample slot number) but expect a different sample (for example, one uses a piano sample while the other uses a trombone sample), you will need to edit at least one of the programs and put the sample in a different slot. Ideally the Nord Sound Manager would take care of this.

title: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: Quick question-I own an Electro 3 and am thinking about picking up the Nord Wave.  The NE3 has the left output labeled as Mono.  For live use, I don't need stereo output.  The Nord Wave back panel does not designate a mono output.  In order to get the entire signal out of the Wave, do I have to use both left and right outputs?

title: RE: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: I just asked the same question!  Hope someone knows the answer.

title: RE: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: DJKeys wrote:....The Nord Wave back panel does not designate a mono output.  In order to get the entire signal out of the Wave, do I have to use both left and right outputs?Hi DJKeys,While I don't own the Nord Wave, I found one in a local music shop over the weekend and decided to investigate.You are correct that the Nord Wave doesn't have a summing jack and therefor requires both Left and Right audio outputs to be connected.I took a peek in there with a flashlight, usually an instrument that sums on one jack, has a normally closed contact in the opposite sides' jack.This contact would parallel the two audio signals together like a Y-cable. I didn't see this in the Nord Wave.My recommendation would be to use a Y-cable to sum the two outputs whenever you want to run in mono.Themanualmakes reference to it being a true stereo signal path. As I interpret this, even if you were to start with a monaural sample, you'd still encounter issues with the stereo effects section "if not using a Y-cable to do the summing".Feel free to contact Nord technical support for confirmation at this link:http://www.nordkeyboards.com/main.asp?t ... al_supportI hope this helps.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: Petrounic wrote:Any idea to use only one cable on nordwave(MONO)? If i  connect only one cable on left output it's ok?like other keyboards ( korg,yamaha)Hi Petrounic,you have to use a Y-cable to sum the Left and Right into one cable for monaural use.I gave a more detailed response here:http://www.norduserforum.com/nord-wave- ... -t769.htmlCheers, Hanon

title: RE: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: As DJKeys quickly found out, the Y-cable summing of two sides of a stereo signal does NOT always yield results which are desirable.  Arbitrarily "mixing" via this means can cause all sorts of weird phase cancellation effects and usually sounds like @#*@#%, depending on the nature of the timbre(s) being played.Stereo signal is provided for studio situations and for those rare live situations where the house sound system is stereo.  For most common live situations where only a mono send is needed, just take one side or the other -- it doesn't really matter which.  This is not a situation which can be compared to ordering a steak at a restaurant and cutting it two pieces when it arrives to the table only to throw half in the garbage.  With the exception of programs with extreme tremolo/panning effects in use, you won't really be losing any meaningful portions of the audio signal, and you'll be sparing your ears from having to listen to a phase-cancelled mess.Anyone wanting a longer, more drawn-out discussion of this can reply to this post and I'll supplement, but that's the heart of the matter.  I should also point out that, although I am employed as Nord Tech Support USA/Canada, views and opinions expressed here are not official corporate policy either of Nord or of AM&S, their US distributor, but my own views and opinions.Pablo Mastodon

title: RE: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: Pablo has hit the nail on the head.  I have done a lot of experimentation with this and except for stereo panning and some other effects the signal out of the L and R jacks is essentially the same. I record the Wave in Stereo but play live in mono with just one output and it sounds fine.

title: RE: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: Interesting,I can understand this for a simple synth waveform.But, if you used a stereo sample that was recorded hard panned with different elements Left and Right.Using just one output instead of both would yield satisfactory results?I'm puzzled by this part of the manual then:Nord Wave Manual wrote:Featureson page 5The Nord Wave is also a true stereo synthesizer, the signal paths forthe left and the right outputs are separated at the very core in thesound engineCheers, Hanon

title: RE: MONO mode on Nordwave
post_content: As DJKeys found out, it is using both outputs into mono via a Y-cable which is much more likely to yield unsatisfactory results.Let's take some real world examples: a piano and a rack of toms.  You mic each in stereo.  Both mics will pick up both ends of both instruments, but there will be phase differences due to distance traveled from string/tom to mic.  In order to create an authentic stereo playback it is necessary to hear both sides.  But you still aren't really losing anything, other than perspective, by giving up either one of the two sides.In my view, it is natural to have this sort of gut feeling that by not taking both sides of the signal, one is somehow missing out on something, but properly analyzed that is not actually the case.  It's more like covering up one ear...you still hear everything.  The difference is you are hearing it from only one perspective, instead of from the two perspectives which stereo would provide.  The point is, generally speaking, you are not actually missing any content, not when we are talking about ordinary real world examples.However, sometimes the electronic instrument world takes real world examples to the extreme, as in the case of a Fender Rhodes on hard panning tremolo.  In that kind of a case, the oscillating volumes of the two sides of the stereo field, 180 degrees out of phase with one another, will result in completely changing the character of the resulting sound when you remove either side.  Those kinds of things do not occur with acoustic instruments -- the halves of the stereo field are not so extremely segregated from one another.Understanding how and why these things can occur, and that they occur only rarely in particular circumstances, will help one to avoid those situations in one of three ways: don't use those kinds of effects settings when being forced to run a single mono feed, or run both sides of the signal, or live with it.  Sometimes "mistakes" make for new creativity!  Also, in many of these cases (I think), the issue is not so much that the house system is mono (which it usually is), but that the mixing board is cramped for space and the engineer doesn't want to give the keyboards two channels for one instrument.There will be very few situations in which taking only one side of the stereo feed will yield unsatisfactory results...Bless,Pablo

title: Problems to load sounds in the Sound Manager
post_content: I have now a Nord Wave and downloaded the whole sounds of the Clavia site, but I do not get the sounds into the North Sound Manager (and from there to the Nord Wave)!The sounds I get into the sound manager have the extension "nwp". The sounds that I can NOT put in the Sound Manager (Sounds of NL2x, NL3, G2, etc.) have the extension "nsmp". What should I do?

title: RE: Problems to load sounds in the Sound Manager
post_content: A NWP file is a Nord Wave Program file - it contains oscillator settings, etc. A NSMP is a Nord Sample file and contains just a sample, not a complete instrument. If an instrument (NWP) configures oscillator 2 to use a sample as its source (SAMP setting), the complete instrument would consist of both a NWP and a NSMP file.The files you can download from the Nord site are (collections of) samples of existing instruments, they are not recreations of these instruments even though the Wave might be able to recreate them in some cases (such as some Nord Lead sounds). To use these sounds, you first need to add them to the sample library (Samp Lib) on your Nord Wave. You do this with the Nord Sound Manager (the other program, Nord Sample Editor, is for creating your own NSMP files).Start the Manager and click on 'Samp Lib' below the row of buttons at the top; Samp Lib stores your samples (NSMP files) and Program your programs (NWP). To add a sound, click on 'Sound Down' in the button bar at the top and find your sound. It is now added to the Samp Lib. Note the location (a number) of the sample. Normally the manager software will just pick the first free slot, but if you click on the Organize button on the left of the button bad, you can select the exact slot you want to place the sound in. You can also move and rename sounds in the manager.Now you've loaded the sample in the Wave, create a new sound to start with. Keep the 'shift' (the grey button just above the wooden pitch stick) button pressed and then press on the mono mode button (to the left of the volume know at the top-left). This initializes a new sound (sound init). Now do the same for samp init (shift + vibrato button, just to the left of the mono mode button) - this sets up some default settings for playing samples. The LED display for oscillator 2 should now show a number, this is the currently selected sample number. Set it to the sample you uploaded earlier and give it a try. If the number is blinking, it is pointing to a location that currently does not contain a sample.This gets you a starting point. You can now use the rest of the functionality of the Wave to sculpt the sound to your liking. In my opinion, using the Wave just to play samples as-is is better done using other keyboards.Of course, this information is also in the user manual, but I'm feeling in a generous mood

title: RE: Problems to load sounds in the Sound Manager
post_content: Thanks man! I'll try it out!

title: RE: Outputs assignment ?
post_content: You can't. You might be able to fake something if you limit yourself to using samples on OSC2, where slot A would have silence on the right channel and slot B silence on the left channel (or vice versa, of course). You'd need to be careful with the effects, too. You can use the reverb in mono mode (don't enable stereo) and the chorus function might work a bit differently, since it seems to work mostly on the difference in the left and right channel (which is rather big in this case).I doubt it's worth the trouble, really. If it even works.

title: RE: Velocity split and RAM ?
post_content: Hello zgogor,Welcome to the forums!Yes,there is a velocity crossfade "split" available to the Nord Wave.In short, you use the Note Velocity via the Morph function to inversely control the volume of two samples (Slot A sound vs Slot B sound).More information on how to do it can be found on page 13 of the manual.I wouldn't hold your breath for Clavia's reply to the memory part of the question. I don't believe they have anything to gain by publicly answering, but you could email your question to them.Cheers, Hanon

title: The Nord Wave and synth sample library sounds
post_content: I am considering buying a Nord Wave at some stage in the future to supplement my Stage EX.Forgive my ignorance, but if I were to (for example) download Mini Moog samples from the Clavia Sample Library, would I be able to alter filter/LFO settings of the Moog sounds or would I be limited to applying effects (and maybe layering Wave sounds) to the provided samples? I assume that ASDR variation would be easily achievable.I hope I've explained my question clearly.

title: RE: The Nord Wave and synth sample library sounds
post_content: DoctorC wrote:but if I were to (for example) download Mini Moog samples from the Clavia Sample Library, would I be able to alter filter/LFO settings of the Moog sounds or would I be limited to applying effects (and maybe layering Wave sounds) to the provided samples? I assume that ASDR variation would be easily achievable.Hello DoctorC,The Nord Wave uses the samples just like oscillators, which can then have modulations applied, pass through multimode resonant filters, and be modulated by ADSR controlled envelopes.In short, just like any synthesizer.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Waveforms in the analog category

title: RE: Waveforms in the analog category
post_content: Dieguet wrote:Another question is if you can split the keyboard, I know that there is no split function but I read somewhere that there is a way to do it.Besides the method already mentioned (creating a sample that has different sounds above and below a certain point), I believe you can split any two sounds by assigning one to Slot A on, for example, MIDI channel 1, and one to Slot B on MIDI channel 2; set the Wave to Local Off; send the MIDI output of the Wave to an external MIDI processor that can send all keys below a certain note to channel 1 and all notes above to channel 2; and then connect the output of the processor to the MIDI input of the Wave.There used to be a number of companies making MIDI processors. Currently, the only one in production that I know of ishttp://www.midisolutions.com/prodevp.htm# though you could probably also do it with various computer programs if you have your Wave hooked up that way.One of the limitations of the Wave is also that you can't send the Slot A sound out the left output and Slot A out the right (or vice versa). So if you want a split where the two sounds are output separately, you're probably back to just the sample method... where you can not just put different samples above or below a certain note, but you should also be able to put one sample just on the left channel and the other just on the right.

title: RE: slot A & B
post_content: This is from the manual:Sound InitBy pressing the Sound Init button (Shift + Mono Mode buttons),the settings of the Slot in focus will be initialized. This provides you witha neutral starting point if you want to program a sound from scratch.• The settings of the oscillator waveforms, oscillator mix and the programeffects will be excluded from the initialization. The effects will beturned off for the Slot but the actual settings will not be changed.Initialize both slots, then put the same waveform in each with the exact same settings.-dj

title: RE: Nord Wave 2
post_content: Hi guysJust thought I would let you know that the nord wave does effectively allow a keyboard split feature. You can morph between the slot A sound and the slot B sound in three ways, by using the mod wheel, using velocity, and using the keyboard.If you use the keyboard you can have one sound in the lower register which morphs into another sound in the higher register. In the middel of the keyboard you get both sounds mixed. I appreciate this isn't a defined split, but the effect sounds great in my opinion when used with classic combos such as string bass and piano.

title: RE: Program increment
post_content: raabix wrote:First of all hi everyone on this forum!I really enjoyed answering the registration question to verify that I am not some random program trying to register "What is the subdominant key of an A major chord" - This also prevents Nonßmusicians from entering the forumAnyways, heres my question that I couldn't find an answer to:Is there a midi message to increment/decrement programs on the nord wave. I am often playing the wave from my master keyboard and I would like to browse through the programs without walking over to my nord wave. The manual doesn't say anything about that and my google-efforts have ben unsuccessful so far.Thanks and cheers,RuedigerHello Ruediger,Welcome to the forum!Other than the program change message itself, there's no increment/ decrement program midi message that your Wave will respond to.If your master controller is setup to send program changes, and the Wave is set for "MIDI Program Change Mode" = RCV, on the proper midi channel #, it will respond.If not, please post back with the type of master controller that you're using and one of us will help further.Cheers, Hanon

title: RE: Program increment
post_content: There is no 'next program' message in the general MIDI specification. If you're on program 126 in bank 1 on your Wave and you press Up, the Wave generates a MIDI message that says 'select program 127'. If you press Up again, it will generate two messages: 'select bank 2' and 'select program 1'.I have the MIDI out on my Wave going to a Waldorf Blofeld which sits on top op the Wave (the right side of a Nord Lead/Wave are great of placing small synth or stomp boxes on, but beware of scratches on the pretty red paint job), so I can use the program buttons on the Wave to select programs on the Blofeld. If I have the Sort Mode set to anything else than Numerical (so Alphabetical or by Category) things don't work as expected and the Blofeld seems to jump through its preset in an almost random fashion. This is because the Sort Mode causes the Wave to no longer go through programs in a linear fashion - it will send out a bank and program number for the new program. If the Blofeld itself has a non-standard sort mode (such as by Category) that is ignored.

This allows me to keep my bank and program selections independent from the two keyboards. Just today I figured out, that you can program the buttons have an incremental mode which also works with program changes, so that each time I tap it it increments its value - which is perfect. There is no decrement mode, but good enough for browsing through the banks.@mjbrands: I haven't checked the blofeld yet. This is something for later. I recall seeing some japanese guy in a youtube video creating some really bizarre sounds with it, but for now I really appreciate the straight-forward workflow with the Nord Wave.Cheers,Ruediger

title: RE: Wave MIDI problems
post_content: I was stupid enough to upgrade my Mac to Lion, so I can't use Live right now to verify anything.Some questions though:- Did you set up your midi interface correctly in Live?- Does the midi indicator in Live blink if you hit a key or turn a knob on the Wave?You need to enter midi map mode in Live to tell Live to which controls you want to map knobs on the Wave. You enter midi map mode (your screen will turn 'blue' when you enter midi map mode), click on whatever control you want to control from the Wave and then touch the control you want to use on the Wave. If you can't click on the controls in the VST itself, you may need to first set up a macro in Live and then select that.Maybe you should first set up controlling a native Live device from the Wave, so you know you've got Live, your midi interface and your Wave set up correctly. Alter that you can mess with specific VST plugins.Look at the 2nd post on this page for VST and macro's:http://forum.ableton.com/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=158623

title: RE: Wave MIDI problems
post_content: Hello kryonso,Welcome to the forum!The previous post by mjbrands addresses some important considerations.I have a few things to add:The MIDI LED on the Wave only flashes when receiving MIDI, not when sending it.I'm assuming that you're using the Korg Zero8 as a MIDI interface for the Wave to communicate to the PC.Are you connecting the Zero8 to the PC via FW or USB?I believe that there is a Korg driver configuration to enable the MIDI thru mode to work on the Zero8.Does Ableton see MIDI coming from the Zero8?Cheers, Hanon

title: Oscilator Modulation
post_content: Hi, I´m a Wave and Stage Compact Classic owner and I´m a happy man.The sounds that I´ve ever loved from my favourite bands (Yes, Genesis, King Crimson), now I can play them...Although, it´s difficult for me to create good sounds using the Oscilator Modulation, in general they became distorted.It would be useful to share your experiences with this Wave feature.Thanks.Diego

title: RE: Oscilator Modulation
post_content: Hello Diego,The Oscillator Modulation feature is used for creating Frequency Modulation, or Phase Modulation type effects.The most common example of Frequency Modulation (FM) is the sounds produced by the Yamaha DX series synths of the early 80s.The most common example of Phase Modulation (PM) is the sounds produced by the Casio CZ series synths of the mid 80s, although they called it Phase Distortion.Both FM and PM styles of synthesis have proven difficult to program with intuitive results "unlike with subtractive synthesis techniques".One important step toward getting more pleasing results with FM, or PM in to turn the audio output of the modulating oscillator off, because most, if not all of the important work that the modulating oscillator (OSC 2) is doing is reshaping the waveform "harmonic content" of OSC 1.There is some good reading found on the net about FM, and PM.I hope this helps.Cheers, H

Keybed is good (don't understand the complaints about this), has resistance and playability.6. title: Some very nice Videos on the Nord Wave.
post_content: I am currently looking for two new boards to get in the (not so near unfortunately) future. One will be a weighted 88 key board after I sold my Roland RD Stagepiano, probably a Kurzweil PC3x/K. The other one should be a small footprint versatile board mainly for Synth and if possibly sample playback. While a Moog Voyager would be great, it is currently out of my price range and is a bit too heavy. So when I played the other day around with a Nord Wave, I was impressed how flexible it was! While the keybed certainly is not its strongest point, I liked the sounds and easy tweakability. On youtube, I then found a bunch of crappy videos but also three really excellent ones, so enjoy:[youtube][/youtube][youtube][/youtube][youtube][/youtube]
